i - developed - cancer - on - my - legs - after - insect - bite - double - amputee - businessman : 

senior citizen and businessman , amidu(PERSON) oyebanji(PERSON) , whose legs were amputated after being diagnosed with kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma , shares his story with ajibade omape 

what is your background ? 

my name is akande amidu(PERSON) oyebanji(PERSON) , i am from oyo(ORG) state(ORG) , where i was born and got all my education . i was born in ibadan(GPE) on april(DATE) 27(DATE) ,(DATE) 1967(DATE) . i am from a family of muslims(NORP) . 

why were your legs amputated ? 

i was diagnosed with a type of cancer called kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma by doctors at the(ORG) university(ORG) college(ORG) hospital(ORG) , ibadan(GPE) , and i was advised by the doctors that if i wanted to live , my leg had to be cut off because it was infected with kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma . at the time , i had an insect bite on my left leg and it was that leg that was first(ORDINAL) cut off ; however , my right leg got amputated almost(DATE) three(DATE) years(DATE) later(DATE) after the same symptoms resurfaced . 

in your video on social media , you mentioned that you suffered an insect bite on your toe . what happened after that ? 

about(DATE) six(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) , i had an insect bite on the toe of my left leg ; it was tiny just like when someone gets bitten by a mosquito , and it was not painful so i did not pay attention to it and i continued with my work and life was going smoothly ; it later became a little boil on the toe and grew bigger as time went by . i then decided to pop it with a pin hoping that the pus and blood in it would come out so that it could heal perfectly . days(DATE) later(DATE) , i noticed that the injury was a little damp so i started to nurse it and clean it up . i went to baptist(ORG) hospital(ORG) in ogbomoso(LOC) where i was given medications to use and also taught how to clean it up . 

after a while , my wife , who is also a health worker , noticed that the surface was getting wider so she advised me to go to the hospital because the wound was not healing . i went back to the hospital where i saw a young doctor who was a junior doctor in the department , who advised me to go to a bigger hospital to get proper care . i was confused as to why but he advised that i either go to the teaching hospital in ilorin or the(ORG) university(ORG) college(ORG) hospital(ORG) in ibadan(GPE) ; i decided to go to ibadan(GPE) since that was where i have lived all my life , so the doctor wrote a referral letter for me that i took to the uch where we conducted a series of tests , samples were taken from the open wound and taken to the laboratory . 

it took three(DATE) months(DATE) before the result was out and that was when i was told that i had kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma . my family was sad , so we opted for local remedies , consultation , and herbs to treat it for about(CARDINAL) four(CARDINAL) to(CARDINAL) five(CARDINAL) months(CARDINAL) , but there was no solution so i went back to the hospital where i was advised that the leg would have to be amputated if i wanted to save my life . i agreed saying if that was the will of god for me , so be it . on september(DATE) 29(DATE) ,(DATE) 2019(DATE) , my left leg was amputated as a result of kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma . after it had been amputated , i received treatment and started using crutches ; i was told not to come to the hospital again because my system was clean . 

when it was about(DATE) two(DATE) years(DATE) and seven(DATE) months(DATE) after my left leg was amputated , the second(ORDINAL) leg started showing similar symptoms to the first(ORDINAL) ; i sought traditional treatment again to find out if it was the same issue as the first(ORDINAL) , but all efforts did n’t yield the desired result , so we went back to the uch where they diagnosed kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma and the doctors said they would have to cut off the second(ORDINAL) leg to save my life , i agreed and that was how the second(ORDINAL) leg was amputated on september(DATE) 3(DATE) ,(DATE) 2022(DATE) . 

what job were you doing before losing your legs ? 

i am a businessman , and i used to travel to neighbouring countries dealing in foodstuffs like rice , beans , and so on . i have not been able to do business again because mobility is one of the issues that i am facing . i used to go from lagos(GPE) to cotonou(PERSON) and other neighbouring countries . i went to cotonou(PERSON) through the lagos route and i ended up in sokoto(GPE) ; it was part of the business 

what about your wife and children ? 

my wife is very fine ; she has stood by me ever since this incident occurred ; she did not leave me to myself , and my children as well have been very supportive . i thank god that they are all in good health and they have been with me ever since . they are the reason i still have hope . 

have your siblings supported you when you lost your legs ? 

yes , my siblings have supported me in every way . even my younger ones are instrumental in my upkeep and i ’m very grateful to them for their support . 

you mentioned that you were diagnosed with kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma , how did you get it ? 

well , like i said earlier , my left foot just started getting bigger after the insect bite . i have never broken a bone or nail since i was born , i am always very careful so i am sure i did not contract it from an infected person although , according to the doctors , i can say that the kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma was as a result of the wound on my foot , which was from an insect bite , and at the time i got bit by the insect , i did not even feel it so i had no idea when i got bitten ; the opening was as tiny as that of a mark made by an injection needle . 

what kind of job do you hope to do now ? 

the first(ORDINAL) thing is to get properly taken care of because there is nothing on the ground at the moment ; if you remember from the video on the internet , i mentioned that i wanted to buy artificial legs and the legs will cost about(MONEY) n3(MONEY) m(MONEY) ; i also need to go through physiotherapy , which will also cost a lot . i have been blessed by god(PERSON) ; i previously owned a truck that i once gave to a driver , but at the moment , i do not have it again because when the sickness came , i spent everything i had on it , and there is nothing left right now ; i am just grateful that my wife can support me as i ca n’t do anything for now . 

have you ever attempted suicide because of what happened ? 

no , i have never thought of it ; i can never do such a thing . i love my wife and i love my children as well so i can not even dream of it . i ca n’t leave them to suffer in this world , however , because of my human nature i feel sad sometimes . but i ca n’t do such a thing to myself , so even if i do n’t have money , i have my wife and children . i do n’t fall sick often , although about(DATE) seven(DATE) days(DATE) after the ramadan fasting , i usually have malaria , but once my wife gives me chloroquine injection and paracetamol and i fall asleep , i would be alright after a(DATE) few(DATE) days(DATE) and it could take till the(DATE) following(DATE) year(DATE) before(DATE) i(DATE) fall(DATE) sick again . but i only take this as my fate . 

as a result of your condition , will you say you are depressed ? 

to be very honest , i am human so i feel sad sometimes when i think about it . sometimes i want to go out but i ca n’t because i have no legs to move ; i have clothes in my wardrobe that i can not wear because i can not go anywhere , i just shuffle between two(CARDINAL) pieces of clothes because there is nowhere i am wearing my other clothes too ; so yes , i feel sad sometimes when i also remember the places i have travelled to for business 

you mentioned in your video that you needed to wash your internal organs , is it as a result of the cancer ? 

at the moment , i am no longer in control of my body , so i am always acting on the instructions of the doctors . according to the doctors , the cancer did not spread past my legs so i am safe ; however , cancer is a disease that can not be predicted . i had 10(CARDINAL) chemotherapy sessions , but the doctors said physiotherapy is important for me to be rest assured that my system is free of the cancer . 

how have your friends and other people treated you since your legs were cut off ? 

honestly , people change with time . some of the people , whom i used to do business with and who even owe me , and have seen my present condition , do not even respond to my calls again ; most times when you call these people , all you will hear are prayers and they do n’t even wish to pay up the money they owe ; humans will always be humans . 

how do you manage to get around and do things ? do you have someone assisting you ? 

i mostly crawl ; i do n’t even have a wheelchair . i ca n’t even get a wheelchair because it will require someone to be available to assist me , but my children have different lives to live . coping is not easy but my wife tries her best and every other person around like my children and siblings also try their best to support me , that is one of the reasons why i posted a video on the internet , just like people advised that i speak up hoping that i could get help . 

have you been cured of kaposi(PERSON) sarcoma ? 

only god knows what we do n’t know ; according to doctors , cancer is a disease that can not be predicted , and they have also said that there are no signs of cancer in my system again . however , the doctors advised that i go for physiotherapy so that i can thoroughly rid my body of it and be sure that it is completely out of my system . but yes , there is no cancer in my system anymore as i speak to you . 

you mentioned that you lost about(CARDINAL) 500(CARDINAL) bags of rice to the customs , have you been able to get them back ? 

this happened about(DATE) three(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) at the time when the government said that we should not import rice into the country and there was no other way for us to convey it ; we did not steal it so we could not throw it away , and of course , there is no way the customs will return goods that they seize from you ; i can say that it was part of the rice that was sold cheaply to members of the public and those goods are what we use to feed our families . 

you said you needed n2 m for physiotherapy , how much have you realised from that amount ? 

honestly , i have realised a part of the money meant for physiotherapy . i have realised a total of n1,650,000(PRODUCT) so i am left with a balance of n350,000(GPE) for the physiotherapy , i also need n3,000,000(PERSON) for artifical legs so i would be able to move around . 

having artificial legs will be better than a wheelchair because someone who has a wheelchair has to employ an assistant , but with the artificial legs , i will be able to move about freely and do a lot of things by myself . it will cost about(MONEY) n3(MONEY) m(MONEY) to get one(CARDINAL) but i have not seen anything for that one yet . getting an artificial leg will enable me to move about and get my job done efficiently . 

what support do you need at the moment ? 

i would love people to help me get the necessary things that i need . i am not picky at the moment as beggars ca n’t be choosers , and i also understand the current situation of the country and how it is affecting everybody . i ca n’t ask people to donate money for my physiotherapy and still ask them for money to start a business , i just want help to sort out the physiotherapy bills and get the artificial legs . i just want to take good care of myself and i hope people can support me in any way that they can .

why are you making commenting on the herald only available to subscribers ? 

it should have been a safe space for informed debate , somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the(DATE) day(DATE) , but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off - topic discussions and abuse . 

heraldscotland.com is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment . 

we are doing this to improve the experience for our loyal readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers , who occasionally find their way onto our site , to abuse our journalists and readers . we also hope it will help the comments section fulfil its promise as a part of scotland(GPE) 's conversation with itself . 

we are lucky at the herald . we are read by an informed , educated readership who can add their knowledge and insights to our stories . 

that is invaluable . 

we are making the subscriber - only change to support our valued readers , who tell us they do n't want the site cluttered up with irrelevant comments , untruths and abuse . 

in the past , the journalist ’s job was to collect and distribute information to the audience . technology means that readers can shape a discussion . we look forward to hearing from you on heraldscotland.com 

comments & moderation 

readers ’ comments : you are personally liable for the content of any comments you upload to this website , so please act responsibly . we do not pre - moderate or monitor readers ’ comments appearing on our websites , but we do post - moderate in response to complaints we receive or otherwise when a potential problem comes to our attention . you can make a complaint by using the ‘ report this post ’ link . we may then apply our discretion under the user terms to amend or delete comments . 

post moderation is undertaken full - time 9am-6pm(CARDINAL) on weekdays(DATE) , and on a part - time basis outwith those hours.read the rules here

how - humans - lost - their - tails - and - why - the - discovery - took-2 - 5 - years - to - publish.html : 

ewen(PERSON) callaway(PERSON) in nature : 

geneticist bo(PERSON) xia(PERSON) asked that question as a child and it was on his mind again a(DATE) few(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) , while he was recovering from a tailbone injury during his phd at new(ORG) york(ORG) university(ORG) ( nyu(ORG) ) in new(GPE) york(GPE) city(GPE) . xia(PERSON) and his colleagues now have an answer . the researchers identified a genetic change shared by humans and other apes that might have contributed to their ancestors ’ tail loss , some(DATE) 25(DATE) million(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) . mice carrying similar alterations to their genomes had short or absent tails , the researchers found — but that insight was hard won . the work was published on 28(CARDINAL) february1(WORK_OF_ART) : nearly(DATE) 900(DATE) days(DATE) after being submitted to nature and posted as a preprint , because of extra work needed to develop several strains of gene - edited mice and demonstrate that the genetic changes had the predicted effect . 

“ respect to the authors , ” says malte(PERSON) spielmann(PERSON) , a human geneticist at kiel(ORG) university(ORG) in germany(GPE) , who reviewed the paper for nature . “ i ’m incredibly excited about the fact that they ’ve really pulled it off . ” 

the mice with no tails 

unlike most monkeys , apes — including humans — and their close extinct relatives do n’t have tails . their coccyx , or tailbone , is a vestige of the vertebrae that constitute a tail in other animals . finding the genetic basis for this trait was n’t what xia , now at the broad institute of mit and harvard(ORG) in cambridge(GPE) , massachusetts(GPE) , planned to devote his phd to . but his coccyx injury , sustained during a cab ride , reinvigorated his tail curiosity . 

more here .

the(PERSON) -(PERSON) iss(PERSON) - has - sprung - an - air - leak - but - nasa(ORG) - says - theres - no - need - to - panic : 

russia(GPE) 's space agency said on wednesday(DATE) that its section of the international space station is again suffering an air leak issue , but said the problem currently poses no threat to its crew . 

" indeed , specialists are detecting an air leak on board the iss , " the press service of roscosmos(ORG) said on wednesday(DATE) , per a translation by interfax . 

" there is no threat to crewmembers or the station itself , " roscosmos added . 

space officials said russian(NORP) crew are " regularly " working to identify and fix potential leaks on the iss , per state media agency tass(ORG) . 

the announcement came shortly after national(ORG) american(ORG) space(ORG) agency(ORG) iss program manager joel(PERSON) montalbano(PERSON) on the(DATE) same(DATE) day(DATE) reported an air leak in russia(GPE) 's zvezda life support module during a press briefing for the new crew-8 mission . 

according to montalbano , the leak is small but growing . 

" there is an area at the end of the international space station that we 've seen a leak . there is a small leak . we saw a leak increase about(DATE) a(DATE) week(DATE) before the recent progress launch and docking , " he said . 

montalbano added that nasa(ORG) was working with roscosmos on the issue and that the leak is neither affecting crew safety nor disrupting the crew-8 mission , which aims to send four(CARDINAL) astronauts to the iss(NORP) . 

nasa(ORG) and roscosmos(ORG) found an air leak in russia(GPE) 's side of the iss in august(DATE) 2020(DATE) . it was in the zvezda module , which provides critical life support like oxygen and water . 

this leak source was identified in october(DATE) 2020(DATE) and temporarily patched up , but another possible leak spot was found in november(DATE) 2021(DATE) by russian(NORP) cosmonaut pyotr(PERSON) dubrov(PERSON) . 

roscosmos(ORG) said in january(DATE) 2022(DATE) that the " last air leak " location in the zvezda had been discovered and would be fixed . 

however , the announcement on wednesday(DATE) indicates that the problem has resurfaced . 

russia(GPE) is set to pull out of the iss after 2024(DATE) , moscow(GPE) said in july(DATE) 2022(DATE) , at a time when the us(GPE) announced sanctions targeting russian(NORP) leadership because of the war in ukraine(GPE) .(GPE) 

the station has been one(CARDINAL) of the last remaining points of cooperation between roscosmos and nasa(ORG) , which hopes to continue operating the aging station until 2030(DATE) . 

meanwhile , roscosmos(ORG) said it plans to build its own space station , following the example of china(GPE) 's independent tiangong station . 

as moscow(GPE) continues to split from the west , russian(NORP) space officials have questioned the reliability of the old equipment on board the iss(NORP) .

(PERSON)
paul(PERSON) taylor(PERSON) of the langfield(GPE) riding pony(ORG) &(ORG) dartmoor(ORG) stud sadly passed away on 8(DATE) february(DATE) , after a long and debilitating illness . 

paul(PERSON) was born in 1941(DATE) and lived a full life . in his teens , he showjumped on the yorkshire(GPE) scene , but his real passion for horses and ponies grew when he purchased a dartmoor pony mare , janessa , from lady willingdon(PERSON) at kilbees , and she helped form the start of the highly regarded langfield(PERSON) stud . 

paul(PERSON) and his wife madge bred many successful ponies , including olympia(ORG) winner(ORG) langfield(ORG) canth(ORG) .(ORG) canth was later exported to australia(GPE) to start a new dynasty of dartmoor(ORG) ponies on the other side of the world . a riding pony star was surely langfield(PERSON) harvest time , who was a horse of the(DATE) year(DATE) show winner among many accolades . 

the stud in its(DATE) early(DATE) days(DATE) was based at todmorden , high up on the moors above paul(PERSON) ’s beloved home town of halifax(GPE) in west(GPE) yorkshire(GPE) . around(DATE) 20(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) , they moved to the slightly milder climate of(GPE) york(GPE) in north(GPE) yorkshire(GPE) – but from both locations the stud was highly successful and its bloodlines are very prominent in many successful ponies today(DATE) . 

paul(PERSON) was involved with a number of societies and gave his time and business acumen as a council member to both the national pony society ( nps(ORG) ) and dartmoor(ORG) pony society ( dps ) . he played a key role in nps(LOC) area(LOC) 4(CARDINAL) and was a founder member of the northern dps . 

in later(DATE) years(DATE) , paul(PERSON) ’s happiest times were spent watching his granddaughter lucy(PERSON) compete at the highest level on both dartmoor(ORG) and show hunter ponies . 

paul(PERSON) leaves two(CARDINAL) sons , david(PERSON) and christopher(PERSON) , two(CARDINAL) stepchildren , melissa(PERSON) and daniel(PERSON) , and six(CARDINAL) grandchildren , as well as his devoted wife of almost(DATE) 50(DATE) years(DATE) , madge(ORG) , who shared his great passion for the ponies . we send them all our sincere condolences .

heroes - among - us - air - force - flight - medical - officer - dr(PERSON) -(PERSON) george(PERSON) -(PERSON) chastain(PERSON) : 

heroes among us : air force flight medical officer dr(PERSON) .(PERSON) george(PERSON) chastain(PERSON) 

albany(GPE) , ga(ORG) . ( walb ) - it ’s time to recognize a military hero in south(GPE) georgia(GPE) who served our country and now serves the community . 

air(ORG) force(ORG) flight medical officer dr(PERSON) .(PERSON) george(PERSON) chastain(PERSON) took three(DATE) years(DATE) out of his training during post - grad at emory to go into the air force , but little did he know his mission would change . 

“ i went to vietnam(GPE) and i did what i was supposed to do , but there was a lot of time to do something else , or i could ’ve done a lot of things , ” chastain(ORG) said . 

however , chastain(ORG) chose to visit the orphanage and regularly give needed medical aid to children . the former physician went into the air force and served two(DATE) years(DATE) stateside and was then sent to vietnam(GPE) to serve as a flight medical officer but it was the work he did while he was n’t in the air that impacted him most . 

“ it was a breath of fresh air to me as much as it was anything else because i saw kind , gentle people , ” he said . 

chastain(PERSON) was impressed by the dedication of the nuns who operated the orphanage but also how ill - equipped they were to practice medicine . 

“ i had to be very careful because if i told them something , that they should do it , next thing i know while i was talking they were out there doing it . i mean they just reacted that fast , ” he said . 

being away from his family was difficult , but he cared for the children as if they were his own . 

“ they meant the world to me , and for a long period of time , they were my world , ” chastain(ORG) said . 

when dr . chastain(PERSON) came back home , much like many others who serve in the armed forces suffered from ptsd(GPE) , one(CARDINAL) of the darkest moments in his life . but still , he clung to his faith . 

“ guys over there were losing their faith in their god , it helped me regain mine and that was very important to me , ” chastain(ORG) said .

eight(CARDINAL) in every 10(CARDINAL) board of management teachers goes home with less than sh10,000 at the(DATE) end(DATE) of(DATE) the(DATE) month(DATE) , a report has revealed . 

the finding came during the launch of a report titled , “ the foundational literacy and numeracy assessment ( flana(PERSON) ) report 2023(DATE) " on thursday(DATE) at kicd(ORG) in nairobi(GPE) . 

the report also showed that two(CARDINAL) in every bom teacher earns between sh10,000 and sh20,000(ORG) at the(DATE) end(DATE) of(DATE) the(DATE) month(DATE) . 

one(CARDINAL) in 100(CARDINAL) bom teachers earns between sh20,000(ORG) and sh30,000(NORP) monthly(DATE) . 

additionally , the report showed that sources of funds for payment of bom teachers mostly come from parents of the schools . 

usawa(ORG) agenda executive director emmanuel(PERSON) manyasa(PERSON) said the payment a tutor receives speaks on their motivation to teach learners . 

manyasa(ORG) said most schools are facing the challenge of sourcing funds to pay the bom teachers , who are critical to ensuring the delivery of quality education . 

“ the government should consider factoring in money for bom teachers because parents are not always able to . the source from which the bom teachers are paid comes from parents nationally , ” manyasa(ORG) said . 

the report showed that sh67(ORG) in sh100 paid to bom teachers comes from parents . 

sh70(GPE) in sh100 paid to bom teachers in rural areas come from parents . 

" sh60 in sh100 paid to bom teachers in urban areas come from parents , " the report read in part . 

interestingly , only sh6.7 in sh100 paid to bom teachers comes from government capitation . 

the flana(PERSON) report also showed that sh7 in sh100 paid to bom teachers in rural areas comes from government capitation . 

government capitation only contributes to sh6.2 in sh100 paid to bom teachers in urban areas . 

the reports come after usawa agenda between(DATE) june(DATE) and(DATE) july(DATE) 2023(DATE) visited 1,953(CARDINAL) villages spread across all counties and interviewed 38,634(CARDINAL) household heads reaching 59,201(CARDINAL) children . 

usawa(ORG) agenda also visited 1,813(CARDINAL) primary schools - both public and private and engaged with learners to find out if they were truly learning . 

further , the report showed that regions with few teachers on permanent and pensionable terms have more learners staying out of school than those with more permanent teachers . 

manyasa(ORG) said regions like wajir(PRODUCT) with few teachers on permanent and pensionable terms have the highest number of learners out of school . 

the report showed wajir(ORG) county(ORG) has the lowest percentage of p(ORG) and p(ORG) teachers constituting 63(CARDINAL) in 100(CARDINAL) of their teachers . 

kirinyaga(GPE) county(GPE) has the highest percentage of p(ORG) and p(ORG) teachers constituting 93(CARDINAL) in 100(CARDINAL) of their teachers . 

additionally , the report showed the percentage of school - aged children , aged six(DATE) to(DATE) 15(DATE) years(DATE) in kenya(GPE) who are out of school has increased from 7.5(MONEY) per(MONEY) cent(MONEY) in 2021(DATE) to 8.5(MONEY) per(MONEY) cent(MONEY) in 2023(DATE) . 

seven(CARDINAL) counties with the largest percentage of out - of - school children are all in the arid and semi(TIME) -(TIME) arid(TIME) lands ( asal ) region with mandera(GPE) county(GPE) leading .

287(CARDINAL) - 53bd257a-3026 - 42b1(CARDINAL) - 94f0 - d1518e75c7b1 : 

dallas(GPE) — 

on friday(DATE) , empower , a private company contracted by the state , will fully takeover managing the foster care system for nine(CARDINAL) north(GPE) texas(GPE) counties . 

this will be the second(ORDINAL) phase of the transition to community - based care , which is the state ’s term for private foster care , for dallas(GPE) , collin(GPE) , ellis(ORG) ,(ORG) rockwall(ORG) , kaufman(PERSON) , hunt(GPE) , fannin(GPE) and navarro counties . in this phase , empower , will assume full case management and placement responsibility for all of the children in the region who have been removed from their homes because of abuse and neglect and are in the state ’s custody . 

transitioning to a private system 

in the first(ORDINAL) phase , which went into effect sept(DATE) .(DATE) 1(DATE) ,(DATE) 2023(DATE) , empower took over administrative payments to the child placing agencies and other providers that had had been contracted by the state to provide placement services for foster children . empower also began placing children who entered the state ’s custody after sept(DATE) .(DATE) 1(DATE) . 

the self - titled “ child welfare collaborative ” is a network made up of large nonprofit organizations that have been providing foster care , adoption , residential treatment and behavioral health services for vulnerable children in north(GPE) texas(GPE) for decades(DATE) . those organization , which have historically been contracted by the state of texas(GPE) , will now operate under empower ’s umbrella organization . 

community - based care , or cbc , was introduced by texas(GPE) lawmakers as a solution to the legacy state - run foster care system that ’s historically been plagued with problems and is currently tied up in a 13(DATE) -(DATE) year(DATE) -(DATE) long(DATE) legal battle in which a federal judge ruled that the state of texas(GPE) was violating the constitutional rights of foster care children by placing them in a systemically dangerous system . 

the goal of cbc(ORG) is for non - profit organizations to provide placement and care options to foster children on a localized , region - by - region basis . 

region 3e(CARDINAL) 

region 3e(CARDINAL) is the largest region the state has transitioned to private care . 

“ we ’re responsible for 2,000(CARDINAL) children on any(DATE) given(DATE) day(DATE) whereas the state is responsible for over(CARDINAL) 10,000(CARDINAL) children on any(DATE) given(DATE) day(DATE) , ” empower senior vice president linda(PERSON) garcia(PERSON) said . “ i feel really confident that community - based care is the right thing to do because we are able to concentrate on paying attention to the children that are in this community . ” 

garcia(PERSON) said the state has been moving children to empower ’s care in groups . last(DATE) september(DATE) , the(DATE) first(DATE) month(DATE) of empower ’s first(ORDINAL) phase , dr . garcia(PERSON) said more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 300(CARDINAL) children in paid foster care were transitioned to the company ’s care as(CARDINAL) well(CARDINAL) as(CARDINAL) 112(CARDINAL) children who had been newly removed from their homes . each(DATE) month(DATE) since , groups of a(CARDINAL) few(CARDINAL) hundred(CARDINAL) have been transitioned . 

the last group to be moved over , garcia(PERSON) said , will be children who are living with family and loved ones and children living in specialized living situations . she said that group will be moved over by march(DATE) 1(DATE) , when phase 2(CARDINAL) goes into effect . 

however , while the process of transitioning the children to the new system , one of the greatest concerns about the process from critics of cbc is about empower ’s ability to recruit and retain the experienced child protective services workers who have historically worked for the state . 

staffing concerns 

last(DATE) year(DATE) , dfps(PERSON) told wfaa(ORG) that 450(CARDINAL) of the state ’s more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 700(CARDINAL) jobs in region 3e(CARDINAL) would be moved to empower , meaning that the people in those positions would have to either go to work for empower or find other jobs . 

one(CARDINAL) caseworker , with nearly(DATE) 20(DATE) years(DATE) of experience with dfps , said going private is a major change for herself and her colleagues . 

“ i know there are some people who are forcing themselves to be positive about it because it ’s one(CARDINAL) of those ‘ i ’m going to go into this with a positive mindset and hope for the best ’ , but i do n’t know anyone who is genuinely excited , ” she said . 

the woman said she and her colleagues have been attending town hall - style informational meetings hosted by empower to prepare for the transition , but it has not improved confidence in the system for her or coworkers she ’s spoken with . 

“ it ’s hard to put faith in it when it comes from empower because they ’ve broken every promise that they ’ve made to us , ” she said . 

the caseworkers and other dfps employees are planning to start working for empower on march(DATE) 1(DATE) told wfaa(ORG) that they are taking great financial losses by moving to empower . 

“ we were told that we ’d get pay and benefits that were comparable to what we ’d get with the state and that did not happen , ” the caseworker said . “ it is because of the insurance . right now , the state pays for our insurance . empower , sometimes they ’re matching workers ’ pay . sometimes they ’re offering less , and then we have to pay for our own insurance . " 

in her case , the base pay was matched , but she said she ’s taking a financial hit of about(MONEY) $(MONEY) 13,000(MONEY) in insurance payments . 

“ for some workers , that is going to be a destroying factor , ” she said . 

a supervisor with more(DATE) than(DATE) 20(DATE) years(DATE) of experience with the department told wfaa(ORG) that she is going to work for empower because she feels like she does n’t have a choice . she said that she ’s accumulated multiple months work of paid sick time that she will lose and wo n’t be compensated for . 

“ the people that are going are doing it because they want to stay with their kids , ” the caseworker said . “ some are going for the money because they do n’t have any better options . ” 

when empower entered its first(ORDINAL) phase of this transition last(DATE) september(DATE) , both garcia(PERSON) and leaders with the state admitted that the transition was going to be difficult for staff who have grown accustomed to state pay and benefits . they also admitted it was n’t likely a private nonprofit would be able to compete with state compensation for every employee . 

for garcia(PERSON) , it ’s still a high priority . 

“ we have been busy trying to recruit the department of family and protective services caseworkers , to task them to come over to us , ” garcia(PERSON) said . “ that ’s been weekly(DATE) rounds of interviews and trying to get them to come over to us . ” 

wfaa(ORG) submitted an open records request with dfps for data on what the people in the 450(CARDINAL) jobs going to empower were choosing to do . 

from february(DATE) 2023(DATE) , which is when the state awarded empower its contract , to january(DATE) 8(DATE) of(DATE) this(DATE) year(DATE) , 123(CARDINAL) staff members opted to go to empower , 14(DATE) retired , 15(CARDINAL) people transferred to other state agencies and 71(CARDINAL) transferred within dfps . 

the state did not provide the number of people who resigned , despite that being part of the requested for information . the state also did not respond to follow - up questions about the more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 200(CARDINAL) positions that were not accounted for in the data provided . 

empower said wednesday(DATE) that it ’s hired 339(CARDINAL) new staff members for its second(ORDINAL) stage , with “ around(CARDINAL) 250(CARDINAL) ” started in march(DATE) 1(DATE) . of those 339(CARDINAL) positions , empower said 147(CARDINAL) of the people hired are caseworkers and 34(CARDINAL) of them are support staff hired to assist caseworkers . 

the company said it still has 75(CARDINAL) open positions to fill . 

“ it ’s extremely important for us to have all these individuals with this experience , ” garcia(PERSON) said . “ they know their cases . they know the children . they know the families . they know the community . ” 

the caseworker who spoke with wfaa(ORG) said she is concerned about empower filling positions with people who are less experienced . 

“ we do n’t know who ’s training the new people coming to empower , ” she said . “ we do n’t know what training they ’re receiving . kids will run away when they do n’t feel cared for . worse things can happen when they do n’t feel cared for . ” 

garcia(PERSON) said training programs are in place for new staff . she said empower is hiring for “ every supportive position you can think of ” . 

the caseworker who spoke with wfaa(ORG) for this story said that she already has more cases than the state recommends per caseworker , and she has already received an additional case from a unit where both the supervisor and caseworker have left the department . she is concerned that caseworkers will see higher caseloads as people choose to either not go to empower , or to leave shortly after the transition . 

dr . garcia(PERSON) said empower is working to prepare for that possibility . 

“ what we want to do is over hire just in case because sometimes life changes for these case workers , ” garcia(PERSON) said . “ they may decide they want to remain in the region or they make go somewhere else . ” 

placing children 

in addition to compensation and hiring concerns , caseworkers who spoke with wfaa(ORG) said they are already noticing children being placed in homes and facilities that are outside of region 3e(CARDINAL) . 

“ community - based care is supposed to be about keeping your kids in their community , and they ’re not , ” a caseworker said . “ i ’ve had kids go out of region ... i’ve had two(CARDINAL) that have gone out of region just(DATE) this(DATE) year(DATE) just since december(DATE) . ” 

dr . garcia(PERSON) admitted that more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) half(CARDINAL) of the providers that empower has brought into its network are outside of the nine(CARDINAL) counties of region 3e(CARDINAL) . 

" i ’ve got 160(CARDINAL) in our network but , of that , probably about(CARDINAL) 60(CARDINAL) of them are within the counties in our region , ” garcia(PERSON) said . 

caseworkers said that ’s “ another broken promise ” from empower . 

“ they flat out said ‘ we are not going to place kids out of region , ’ ” a caseworker said . 

one(CARDINAL) of the state ’s performance measures for empower is the percentage of children who are placed within 50(QUANTITY) miles(QUANTITY) of their home . 

“ they can be not in the region and within 50(QUANTITY) miles(QUANTITY) , ” garcia(PERSON) said . 

what ’s next ? will it work ? 

empower will be required to report to dfps in a number of performance measures and will have to meet certain standards in order to maintain its contract with the state . 

“ i ’ve seen improvement in the system every since community - based care was launched in 2013(DATE) , " garcia(PERSON) said . “ i ’ve had the luxury to be in the system from 2013(DATE) on , and community - based care has a way to target the problem and really work . ” 

garcia(PERSON) was in a leadership position with our community our kids ( ocok ) when the organization was awarded the state ’s first(ORDINAL) contract to privatize foster care in region 3w(CARDINAL) which is made up of tarrant(GPE) , parker(ORG) , hood , johnson(PERSON) , somervell(ORG) , palo(GPE) pinto(GPE) and erath counties . in april(DATE) , ocok will add children in denton(GPE) , wise and cookie counties to its care . 

however , some of the caseworkers who spoke with wfaa(ORG) said they are concerned about how the system will work in dallas(GPE) county(GPE) . 

“ it ’s too big , ” a caseworker said . “ fannin(GPE) , navarro(ORG) , ellis ... maybe they ’ll succeed with them , but i do n’t know anybody that has a hope for success in dallas(GPE) . ” 

despite cbc being in place for more(DATE) than(DATE) a(DATE) decade(DATE) in the western part of north(GPE) texas(GPE) , she said many caseworkers are weary after watching it fail in in the san(GPE) antonio(GPE) area . in 2021(DATE) , just(DATE) about(DATE) two(DATE) years(DATE) after the state awarded a contract to the children ’s shelter to takeover foster care in bexar(GPE) county(GPE) , the organization cancelled its contract with the state after the state opened an investigation into a number of issues including violent episodes , sexual assaults and lack of supervision for kids . 

“ a lot of workers are expecting it kind of go the way bexar count went where the outlying counties are able to stay under a company , but the major metropolitan areas was not , ” a caseworker said . 

she said none of the colleagues she ’s spoken with expect privatized care to be a success in region 3e(CARDINAL) -- but they want to be proven wrong . 

“ we want empower to succeed , ” a caseworker said . “ we know the system is broken . we know the department ’s not the best parents ... we want empower to be the solution to our problems . ” 

when asked how the public will know if cbc works for this region , garcia(PERSON) said the reports empower will provide to the state and the community will make it clear . 

“ the data will speak for itself , ” garcia(PERSON) said .

remembering-moorehead-story-lakeland-erased-140527220.html : 

remembering moorehead(PERSON) : the story of lakeland(GPE) ’s erased black community 

lakeland(GPE) , fla(GPE) . ( wfla(GPE) ) -the moorehead(PERSON) community was a bustling neighborhood in lakeland(GPE) for african(NORP) -(NORP) americans(NORP) before desegregation , but nothing remains from the historic town . 

“ willie pearl , ” audrey(PERSON) figgs(PERSON) said . 

“ that would have been here ? ” wfla(ORG) ’s deanne(PERSON) king(PERSON) asked . 

“ that would have been right here , ” she replied . 

audrey(PERSON) figgs(PERSON) , 75(DATE) , remembers the moorehead(PERSON) community as though it was still there . 

“ i can hear my mother right now standing on the porch , ivory(GPE) , ann(GPE) , dawn , audrey(PERSON) and mary(PERSON) , ” figgs(NORP) recalled . “ we had to run through the path to come up and eat everyday at 5(TIME) o’clock(TIME) my mother would call . ” 

figgs(NORP) grew up in moorehead(GPE) , which is where the first(ORDINAL) black school and church were built in lakeland(GPE) . 

“ in 1954(DATE) i went to first(ORDINAL) grade at moorehead(ORG) elementary , ” she said . 

west of downtown lakeland(GPE) , african(NORP) americans(NORP) moved to the 35(QUANTITY) -(QUANTITY) acre(QUANTITY) moorehead(GPE) community in the(DATE) 1800s(DATE) to work on the railroad . roads like lime street , orange street and sycamore street were filled with black - owned businesses , churches and schools . 

“ i remember mt . sinai primitive baptist(ORG) church(ORG) simply because that ’s where we played , ” figgs(NORP) said . “ that was the playground . ” 

in the(DATE) late(DATE) 1960s(DATE) after desegregation , moorehead(ORG) residents were able to visit places they were once not allowed . 

“ i can remember my sister mary(PERSON) telling my momma , ‘ momma , momma look at audrey(PERSON) , she ’s over there drinking that white water , ' ” figgs(NORP) recalled . 

however , shortly after desegregation in 1971(DATE) , the city of lakeland(GPE) purchased moorehead(ORG) using eminent domain to build an auditorium , which is now the rp funding center . 

“ the people were not satisfied , ” figgs(NORP) said . “ they had been on that land since the(DATE) early(DATE) 1800s(DATE) . you just uproot people and move them ? i ’m baffled today(DATE) , i still do n’t understand why mt(GPE) . sinai primitive baptist(ORG) church(ORG) had to go , but yet wonn(GPE) is still there . to me , that ’s blatant discrimination . ” 

wonn(GPE) is a radio station that has been operating since 1949(DATE) . while that was never touched , many families were forced to relocate to areas like westlake(GPE) in lakeland(GPE) . 

“ i was kind of sad to see it go like that because we were one(CARDINAL) big family , ” louise(PERSON) smith(PERSON) said . “ now you drive through here and all you see is cement . ” 

louise(PERSON) smith(PERSON) , 81(DATE) , also grew up in moorehead(GPE) . she moved to the area at 16(CARDINAL) after growing up in georgia(GPE) . 

“ we would have to work the fields in georgia(GPE) , but here i was a cook for my dad , ” smith(PERSON) recalled . “ moorehead(PERSON) was a family . i miss it . ” 

those stories and memories of moorehead now live on through people like figgs(NORP) and smith(ORG) .(ORG) 

“ for people who might not know the story of moorehead(PERSON) , or know that moorehead(PERSON) existed , after learning about it , what do you hope their take away is ? ” wfla(ORG) ’s deanne(PERSON) king(PERSON) asked smith(PERSON) . 

“ that they will value more of where they are at and let them know what people had to give up , ” she said . 

the city of lakeland(GPE) memorialized the moorehead(PERSON) community with a plaque at the now rp funding center . there are archives and photos in the lakeland(GPE) library as well . 

for the latest news , weather , sports , and streaming video , head to wfla(ORG) .

navalny(PERSON) 's mother lyudmila was among the mourners , visiting her son 's grave for the(DATE) second(DATE) day(DATE) , accompanied by the mother of alexei 's widow yulia . both women , dressed in black , stood quietly at the grave , before leaving . 

navalny , who was president vladimir(PERSON) putin(PERSON) 's fiercest critic inside russia(GPE) , died at the(DATE) age(DATE) of(DATE) 47(DATE) in an arctic(LOC) penal colony on feb(DATE) .(DATE) 16(DATE) . supporters said he had been murdered . the kremlin(ORG) has denied any state involvement in his death . 

thousands(CARDINAL) of people attended a farewell ceremony for navalny on friday(DATE) , with some chanting his name and saying they would not forgive the russian(NORP) authorities for his death . 

by saturday(DATE) , the grave in a moscow(GPE) cemetery not for from where he once lived was covered with flowers left by thousands(CARDINAL) of mourners . 

" he was the one who had opened my eyes to the existing political situation in russia(GPE) , " one(CARDINAL) mourner , who did not give her name , said of navalny , who rose to prominence with blogs exposing what he said was vast corruption in the russian(NORP) elite . 

" i followed all of his investigations closely . i showed them to my friends who were not very interested ( in politics ) . i tried to show them to my parents , but that was more difficult . i love truth , i love honesty , and i 'm very happy when truth wins . " 

the kremlin(ORG) dismissed navalny 's accusations of corruption and his accusations that putin(PERSON) had vast personal wealth . navalny 's movement is outlawed and most of his senior allies have fled russia(GPE) and now live in europe(LOC) . 

police look on 

another mourner visited the grave " to honour the memory of the man who has become a symbol of perseverance for me . and after what 's happened , there 's a feeling of a very deep sorrow . " 

" but as horrible as it may sound , it is still pleasant to see how many people came here , and this makes me feel some kind of communion , " the mourner said . 

" he was a symbol . he was a huge symbol . despite everything , you can think of him whatever you want , but he has really become a symbol of something free and bright , of some kind of hope . " 

police looked on but did not interfere as mourners lay flowers at navalny 's grave on saturday(DATE) . 

a rights group , ovd - info , reported that 91(CARDINAL) people had been detained on friday(DATE) in 12(CARDINAL) towns and cities , including moscow(GPE) . it did not immediately report any new detentions on saturday(DATE) . 

navalny had been jailed on a host of charges including fraud , contempt of court and extremism . he denied all those charges , saying they had been trumped up by the authorities to silence his criticism of putin(PERSON) .

45412 - codi - bigsby - trial - begins - the - history - of - no - body - murder - trials - in - virginia(GPE) : 

codi(PERSON) bigsby(PERSON) trial begins : the history of " no body " murder trials in virginia(GPE) 

- details 

- written by laura(PERSON) philion(PERSON) 

- category : local news 

- published : 01 march(DATE) 2024(DATE) 

cory(PERSON) bigsby(PERSON) goes on trial monday(DATE) , charged with the murder of his 4(DATE) -(DATE) year(DATE) -(DATE) old(DATE) son codi — even though no body has been found . whro(PERSON) spoke with former prosecutor and legal scholar laura(PERSON) killinger(PERSON) of william(ORG) &(ORG) mary(ORG) law(ORG) school(ORG) about the history of “ no body ” murder cases in virginia(GPE) . 

the following interview has been edited for length and clarity . 

whro(ORG) : let 's start with the basics . just how difficult is it to try a murder case with no body ? 

laura(PERSON) killinger(PERSON) : well , in any murder case , the prosecutor has to prove that a particular person died at the hands of another person and that the defendant is the one who did that . so in cases where there 's no body , the authorities have to prove that the alleged victim was actually killed and is n't just missing . so it is significantly more difficult than in a regular murder case where you have a body that can be examined by a coroner and that can be identified by loved ones later on as a person who is deceased , and where you can examine the body and determine the method of death . 

whro(ORG) : there are a few cases in virginia(GPE) that set a precedent for this one , including the 1980(DATE) case of the(ORG) radford(ORG) university(ORG) student(ORG) gina(PERSON) hall(PERSON) . it took about(DATE) 40(DATE) years(DATE) for her remains to be found , but steven(PERSON) epperly(PERSON) was convicted for her murder long before that . tell us more about how that case played out legally . 

lk : so that case was sort of a cutting edge case at the time , because it was the first(ORDINAL) ' no body ' case in virginia(GPE) . 

with that case , there was pretty much overwhelming circumstantial evidence . and it was prosecutors piecing together that circumstantial evidence of people who had seen epperly with gina(PERSON) renee(PERSON) hall(PERSON) , and then when they found bloodstains in the cabin , when they found fibers and things like that in the car of the trunk that was identified to connect to epperly . so there 's a lot of circumstantial evidence in that particular case that allowed prosecutors to prove beyond a reasonable doubt . 

there was no statement or confession by epperly , and in fact , epperly maintained his innocence . and despite that , he was convicted and sentenced to life . 

whro : what other kind of evidence can the prosecution present in that case or now in the bigsby case in 2024(DATE) ? are there differences ? 

lk : oh , definitely . certainly the developments in dna evidence have been revolutionary for the criminal justice system , both in identifying and convicting people who did do it , and in exonerating people who did not and who were wrongfully convicted of a crime . so that , of course , is a major factor and difference in these cases since that time . 

in addition , there 's been a lot more developments in other areas of forensic science . so for instance , identification of fibers , identification of hair samples and all kinds of things like that are much better . so there is quite a bit of different technology . 

now , you had mentioned the different types of evidence . circumstantial evidence is something that a lot of times your listeners may have heard about in passing . and there is this mistaken belief out there that circumstantial evidence is not good , and maybe it 's not even admissible , and that 's just simply not true . oftentimes , circumstantial evidence can be extremely helpful in these cases and is usually always admissible . 

whro : cory(PERSON) bigsby(PERSON) made written confessions in jail and then recanted them . a judge ruled in november(DATE) those were admissible . does that change anything about the way this trial would be handled ? 

lk : some people think , " oh gosh , there 's a confession or there 's a statement , is n't that , you know , the end of the story ? " but a good defense attorney can poke holes through a confession . and so as a prosecutor , they will need to find as much cooperating evidence that shows independently that whatever the defendant said the way they did it really is borne out by corroborating evidence , that they find either at the scene or afterward . 

the world changes fast .

friday(DATE) 1(DATE) march(DATE) 2024(DATE) 14:30(DATE) , uk(GPE) 

a man who stabbed to death his ex - partner and a man she was dating in a " ferocious and merciless " attack has been sentenced to a whole life order . 

marcus(PERSON) osborne(PERSON) murdered katie(PERSON) higton(PERSON) , 27(DATE) , and steven(PERSON) harnett(PERSON) , 25(DATE) , in may(DATE) last(DATE) year(DATE) . 

he forced his way into the home he used to share with ms(ORG) higton(ORG) in huddersfield(GPE) and attacked her as she returned from a date at a cinema .

ball - state - names - new - entrepreneurship - center - director : 

ball state names new entrepreneurship center director 

the(ORG) ball(ORG) state(ORG) university(ORG) miller(ORG) college of business on friday(DATE) announced rob mathews(ORG) as the new executive director of the university ’s entrepreneurship center . 

mathews(ORG) is also the executive director of the entrepreneurial leadership institute as well as an assistant teaching professor of management and leadership . he will continue as the director of both centers . 

“ we are delighted to have rob join us in these overlapping roles within the miller(ORG) college of business , ” dean cathy(PERSON) dubois(PERSON) said in a news release . “ his broad experience in these roles and as a facilitator , an entrepreneur , and an author provides him with a well - grounded basis upon which to lead . ” 

mathews(ORG) previously was the entrepreneurship center ’s assistant director . he earned his bachelor ’s , master ’s and doctoral degrees from ball state , and called being able to lead the program in which he was a student an “ incredible honor . ” 

“ my goal is to both honor the robust heritage built by my mentor , dr . don(PERSON) kuratko(PERSON) , while also putting my own stamp on the program through experiential programming centered on problem - solving , innovation , and entrepreneurial leadership , ” mathews(ORG) said . “ i ’m extremely excited for this opportunity and challenge to impact the next generation of entrepreneurs , innovators , and leaders . ” 

the center , which is celebrating its 40th(ORDINAL) anniversary this(DATE) year(DATE) , provides services for students stretching outside the lecture hall , including mentoring , internships and lecture series .

the accused woman has been identified as a 32(DATE) year(DATE) old(DATE) woman named sanghati(PERSON) paul(PERSON) and the victim who was her live - in partner has been identified as sarthak(PERSON) das(PERSON) .(PERSON) reports said that the couple got acquainted with each other through a social media platform and both have been staing in a rented apartment in madhubani(FAC) road(FAC) in kolkata(GPE) . the woman moved in with her partner along with her son from previous marriage . reports said that sarthak(PERSON) was a photographer by profession and he once came home drunk that lead to a verbal fight which took an ugly turn resulting into a gruesome murder . police said that the accused soon called the police and confessed to the crime .

how - immigration - turned - into - a - political - headache - for - biden-20240229 - p5f8rz : 

how immigration turned into a political nightmare for biden 

more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 9(CARDINAL) million(CARDINAL) illegal immigrants have crossed the border since biden(PERSON) took office . with polls showing more voters trust trump on immigration , the president is under the hammer . 

the informal start to the 2024(DATE) presidential race started deep inside texas(GPE) this(DATE) week(DATE) with the two(CARDINAL) most likely presidential contenders facing off over america(GPE) ’s growing immigration crisis . 

split screens on television channels showed live coverage of president joe(PERSON) biden(PERSON) ’s trip into brownsville(GPE) , overlooking the(LOC) gulf(LOC) of(LOC) mexico(LOC) , as former president donald(PERSON) trump(PERSON) inspected the border at eagle pass , in maverick(GPE) county(GPE) . 

it was only biden(ORG) ’s second(ORDINAL) trip to the border since his presidency began in 2021(DATE) , at which time he tore up a long list of the trump administration ’s hardline immigration policies . 

but now he ’s facing a crisis that has spread across the country , from swing states such as arizona(GPE) to democrat(NORP) strongholds such as new(GPE) york(GPE) . 

more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 9(CARDINAL) million(CARDINAL) illegal immigrants have crossed the border since biden(PERSON) took office , heaping pressure on housing , jobs , hospitals and schools and triggering a spate of 33,000(CARDINAL) migrant crimes in 2023(DATE) according to immigration and customs enforcement . 

“ it ’s time to act . it ’s long past time , ” biden(PERSON) said , before pointing the finger at trump and his republican(NORP) colleagues for refusing to support legislation on the issue . 

trump , who visited the border with texas(GPE) governor greg(PERSON) abbott(PERSON) , responded by saying the president had done nothing for three(DATE) years(DATE) and now refused to mention university(ORG) of(ORG) georgia(ORG) student laken(PERSON) riley(PERSON) who was allegedly murdered by a man who entered the us(GPE) illegally in 2022(DATE) . 

“ joe(PERSON) biden(PERSON) will never say laken(PERSON) riley(PERSON) ’s(PERSON) name , but we will say it and we will remember her . i spoke to her parents last(TIME) night(TIME) . we are not going to forget her , ” trump(PERSON) said . 

the former president , who is leading biden by two(CARDINAL) points in national polls , claimed that the number of illegal immigrants that could cross the us(GPE) border might hit 18(CARDINAL) million(CARDINAL) under biden(PERSON) . 

what the polls say 

a gallup(ORG) poll this(DATE) week(DATE) showed that immigration is now the most important problem in the us(GPE) by a plurality of 28(MONEY) per(MONEY) cent(MONEY) , while at the same time , biden(PERSON) ’s trustworthiness on the issue has plummeted . 

in 2020(DATE) , trump was more trusted on immigration by 16(CARDINAL) percentage points , according to an nbc(ORG) news(ORG) polling . that margin more than doubled to 35(CARDINAL) percentage points by january(DATE) . 

more importantly for this year(DATE) ’s election , polling from morning(TIME) consult and bloomberg(PERSON) found that among swing state voters , such as those in the border state of arizona(GPE) , trump(GPE) is more trusted to handle the issue of immigration over biden by 22(CARDINAL) points . 

biden(PERSON) knows the politics of this means he has to steer another course on immigration policies , especially following democrat(NORP) tom(PERSON) suozzi(PERSON) ’s(PERSON) congressional win this(DATE) month(DATE) after his campaign focused on the need to tighten immigration laws . new(GPE) york(GPE) alone is spending $(MONEY) us12(MONEY) billion(MONEY) on the 100,000(CARDINAL) illegal immigrants it has received . 

a fund - raising arm – the house majority pac – spent around(MONEY) $(MONEY) us7(MONEY) million(MONEY) to support suozzi ’s bid , while saying the democrats(NORP) had to go on the offence when it comes to “ immigration ” . 

a democrat(NORP) congressman in new(GPE) york(GPE) ’s(GPE) adjoining wealthy state of connecticut(GPE) , chris(PERSON) murphy(PERSON) , told his democratic(NORP) colleagues , “ we risk losing the 2024(DATE) election if we do not seize this opportunity to go on the offence on the issue of the border ” . 

more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 70(CARDINAL) per cent of surveyed democrats(NORP) rate the government ’s handling of the influx of migrants at the us - mexico border as “ somewhat bad ” or “ very bad ” , according to the pew research centre . 

part of the issue for biden(PERSON) is his demolition of trump(PERSON) ’s tough immigration policies . biden(PERSON) ’s cabinet secretary alejandro(PERSON) mayorkas(PERSON) , whom the(ORG) us(ORG) house(ORG) of(ORG) representatives(ORG) voted to impeach this(DATE) month(DATE) , is now haunted by his quote in 2021(DATE) that , “ we have rescinded so many trump immigration policies , it would take so much time to list them ” . 

apart from biden(ORG) ’s more conciliatory stance to illegal immigrants seeking to live in america(GPE) , he stopped the construction of the border wall system and terminated the migrant protection protocols that sent tens(CARDINAL) of(CARDINAL) thousands(CARDINAL) of alleged asylum seekers to wait in mexico(GPE) – known as the so - called remain in mexico(GPE) policy . 

the director of policy studies at the centre for immigration studies , jessica(PERSON) vaughan(PERSON) , notes biden(PERSON) cancelled a raft of major trump - era policies . 

“ he cancelled agreements with transit nations to offer safe haven to migrants and enforce their borders ; he relaxed application of title 42(CARDINAL) pandemic controls so that minors and families could enter ; he began awarding immigration parole to tens(CARDINAL) of(CARDINAL) thousands(CARDINAL) of illegal crossers , in defiance of the intent of congress(ORG) ; he extended temporary protected status ( tps ) to citizens of more nations and more recent arrivals ; he established strict limitations on interior enforcement to suppress deportations of all but the most egregious criminals ; and launched plans for a new asylum system designed to expedite the legalisation of illegal border crossers , ” she says . 

executive action 

reversing these policies does not require congressional legislative approval despite much being made about debate in congress(ORG) on new legislation . biden(PERSON) knows this and is quietly changing his tune . 

he told us governors this(DATE) week(DATE) that he was working with white(ORG) house(ORG) attorneys on executive actions to limit crossings at the southern border . foremost among the proposals under consideration is a plan to prohibit asylum claims after a certain number of border crossings is reached , allowing the administration to quickly remove individuals without an asylum hearing . 

but analysts at independent political advisory group beacon research say that is not going to be enough to ease the crisis . 

“ any executive action is unlikely to dramatically reduce asylum claims before the election . while taking executive action on immigration could benefit biden , we believe it is unlikely to significantly shift voters ’ opinions of his handling of the issue . ” 

biden(PERSON) is trying to shift the blame onto failed legislation . in may(DATE) last(DATE) year(DATE) , the republican(NORP) - controlled house passed the secure the border act , which reinstated many trump - era policies . democrats(NORP) voted against it and a watered - down bipartisan bill was only recently reintroduced in the senate(ORG) , which a handful of democrats(NORP) voted against and a handful of republicans(NORP) voted in favour . 

“ i did n’t get everything i wanted in that compromise bipartisan bill but neither did anybody else . compromise as part of the process . that ’s how democracy works , ” biden(PERSON) said while addressing homeland security employees in brownsville(GPE) . 

“ those senators who oppose it need to set aside politics and pass it on merits not on whether it ’s going to benefit one(CARDINAL) party or benefit the other party , ” biden(PERSON) added . 

political advertisers from both parties have already spent $(MONEY) us52(MONEY) million(MONEY) on campaign ads about immigration so far this(DATE) year(DATE) . 

it is by far the top issue in terms of political advertising spend , almost(MONEY) $(MONEY) 20(MONEY) million(MONEY) ahead of any other issue according to adimpact data , meaning immigration is looking more like the adjudicator of who takes the(ORG) white(ORG) house(ORG) on november(DATE) 5(DATE) .

russia(GPE) - jails - jehovah : 

russia(GPE) jails jehovah(PERSON) ’s witness for 8(DATE) years(DATE) after ‘ mole ’ secretly films worship meeting 

( reuters(ORG) ) – a court in southwestern russia(GPE) has sentenced a jehovah ’s witness to eight(DATE) years(DATE) in prison after finding him guilty of organising “ extremist activities ” , according to a spokesman for the group . 

russia(GPE) ’s supreme(ORG) court(ORG) designated the christian(NORP) denomination as “ extremist ” in 2017(DATE) , liquidating and banning its nearly(CARDINAL) 400(CARDINAL) chapters across the country . 

russia(GPE) counted roughly(CARDINAL) 175,000(CARDINAL) active believers at the time of the ban , according to the group ’s russian(NORP) website . since then , raids , interrogations and jailings of adherents have occurred with some regularity . 

the case against aleksandr(PERSON) chagan(PERSON) , 52(DATE) , was built around a “ mole ” who secretly filmed worship meetings held by videoconference , said the spokesman , jarrod(NORP) lopes . 

sentenced by a court in tolyatti on thursday(DATE) , chagan(PERSON) is the sixth(ORDINAL) witness to receive eight(DATE) years(DATE) , the longest term imposed since the ban , lopes said . 

religious life in russia(GPE) is dominated by the russian(NORP) orthodox church , which is championed by and loyal to president vladimir(PERSON) putin(PERSON) . some orthodox scholars view jehovah(PERSON) ’s witnesses , known for door - to - door preaching and refusing military service , as a “ totalitarian sect ” . 

at(CARDINAL) least(CARDINAL) 794(CARDINAL) witnesses have been criminally charged in russia(GPE) for their faith , and 127(CARDINAL) are currently serving prison sentences , lopes said . 

last(DATE) month(DATE) , four(CARDINAL) witnesses in the same russian(NORP) region were handed seven(DATE) -(DATE) year(DATE) jail terms in samara(PERSON) , the same region as chagan(PERSON) , while a female believer was sentenced in tolyatti to two(DATE) years(DATE) ’(DATE) forced labour . 

the(ORG) european(ORG) court(ORG) of human rights , the court of the(ORG) council(ORG) of(ORG) europe(ORG) , ruled in june(DATE) 2022(DATE) that the ban was illegal , three(DATE) months(DATE) after the council expelled russia(GPE) over its full - scale invasion of ukraine(GPE) .(GPE)

x - twitter - has - quietly - restored - a - ban - on - misgendering - and - deadnaming - trans - people : 

x / twitter has ‘ quietly restored ’ a ban on misgendering and deadnaming trans people 

ten(DATE) months(DATE) ago(DATE) , in april(DATE) 2023(DATE) , elon musk ’s x platform – formerly twitter – rolled back a vital policy protecting transgender users from misgendering and deadnaming in a move that was widely condemned . 

the move meant that x immediately fell behind other social media companies including tiktok and pinterest , which have both explicitly banned misgendering , deadnaming , misogyny and the promotion of ‘ conversion therapy ’ practices . 

this unpopular decision seemed to come about decision came after elon musk suggested that his own tweets might violate the 2018(DATE) policy , so the rule was quietly dropped . now , it seems that x just as quietly reinstated the original policy – back in january(DATE) 2024(DATE) . 

ars technica reports that , in a section labeled “ use of prior names and pronouns , ” x ’s updated policy confirms that x will “ reduce the visibility of posts that purposefully use different pronouns to address someone other than what that person uses for themselves , or that use a previous name that someone no longer goes by as part of their transition . ” 

lgbtq+ journalist ari(PERSON) drennen(PERSON) picked up the report , tweeting it to her followers and writing , “ do n’t look now but x ( formerly twitter ) quietly restored their ban on misgendering and deadnaming trans people – as long as it ’s reported by the target . ” 

the policy reinstatement comes in the wake of multiple high - profile lgbtq+ organisations and individuals quitting x , citing a rise in anti - lgbtq+ and anti(NORP) -(NORP) trans(NORP) “ hate and vitriol ” on the platform . 

you may like to watch 

x users responded to news of the change , with one(CARDINAL) person tweeting , “ had to go look for myself . it says january(DATE) 2024(DATE) . so very quietly putting it back . i just got a violation for using the word cis . unbelievable . ” 

another person added , “ someone either read enough to widen their perspective or the company was going to get hit with litigation . we will never know unfortunately . ” 

whether this change will have any impact on the overall safety of lgbtq+ people using the platform remains to be seen – it ’s also not clear whether any lgbtq+ organisations who have quit the platform will return . 

non - profit lgbtq+ suicide prevention organisation the trevor(PERSON) project announced its official departure from x in november(DATE) 2023(DATE) , saying , “ lgbtq+ young people are regularly victimised at the expense of their mental health and x ’s removal of certain moderation functions makes it more difficult for us to create a welcoming space for them on this platform . ” 

transgender charity mermaids made a similar announcement in october(DATE) 2023(DATE) – as did lgbtq(PERSON) youth scotland(GPE) and the(ORG) san(ORG) francisco(ORG) lgbt(ORG) centre(ORG) in may(DATE) 2023(DATE) .

article - boeing - reportedly - in - talks - to - buy-737 - fuselage - maker - spirit : 

boeing(ORG) ba(ORG) -(ORG) n(ORG) is in talks to buy its former subsidiary spirit aerosystems spr - n and the planemaker is also delaying plans to ramp up 737(PRODUCT) jetliner production as it tries to get control of a sprawling crisis sparked by a mid - air panel blowout . 

for weeks(DATE) , boeing(ORG) has been reeling from the fallout of the 737(PRODUCT) max incident when a door plug blew off at 16,000(QUANTITY) feet(QUANTITY) ( 4,877(QUANTITY) meters(QUANTITY) ) above the ground on jan(DATE) .(DATE) 5(DATE) . u.s(GPE) .(GPE) aviation regulators have already curbed production and air carriers have been in discussion for more aircraft deliveries with its bigger rival , airbus(ORG) . 

“ we believe that the reintegration of boeing(ORG) and spirit aerosystems ’ manufacturing operations would further strengthen aviation safety , improve quality and serve the interests of our customers , employees , and shareholders , ” boeing(ORG) said in a statement on friday(DATE) . spirit(ORG) aerosystems(ORG) confirmed the discussions . 

in a related development on friday(DATE) , reuters(ORG) was the first(ORDINAL) to report the company told suppliers it was delaying expected increases in plane production as it tries to regain the confidence of the industry and satisfy regulators ’ desires for better oversight of its safety and quality control systems . 

reuters(ORG) reported last(DATE) month(DATE) that years of decentralization of boeing(ORG) ’s planemaking capacity – along with an exodus of experienced workers and aggressive cost - cutting – has affected quality . two(CARDINAL) crashes a(DATE) few(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) dented the confidence of both the public and regulators in boeing(ORG) ’s safety record . 

the first(ORDINAL) crash , of a lion air flight in indonesia(GPE) , occurred in october(DATE) 2018(DATE) and killed all 189(CARDINAL) people aboard . the second(ORDINAL) crash of an ethiopian(NORP) airlines flight in march(DATE) 2019(DATE) killed 157(CARDINAL) people . 

boeing(ORG) spun off spirit in 2005(DATE) and in recent(DATE) years(DATE) has struggled with cost pressures and problems that have slowed aircraft deliveries and thinned its balance sheet . bringing spirit back into the fold could address some of those quality issues as it would give boeing(ORG) more control over manufacturing . 

the preliminary talks were reported earlier on friday(DATE) by the(ORG) wall(ORG) street(ORG) journal(ORG) , which also said that spirit has hired bankers . 

such a move could also help boeing(ORG) lower spirit ’s production costs , a senior industry source told reuters(ORG) . boeing(ORG) had previously considered repurchasing spirit aerosystems , but the optics of buying back at a higher price discouraged such a move , the source said . 

however , spirit ’s shares have fallen 70(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) over the(DATE) last(DATE) five(DATE) years(DATE) , and its $(MONEY) 3.3(MONEY) billion(MONEY) market value is far short of boeing(ORG) ’s $(MONEY) 124(MONEY) billion(MONEY) . “ boeing(ORG) probably realizes that divesting its wichita operations that make up the core of spirit aerosystems was a strategic mistake , ” scott(PERSON) mikus(PERSON) , equity research associate at melius(ORG) research(ORG) said . shares of spirit aerosystems closed up 15(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) on friday(DATE) in regular trading and were up 2.3(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) after hours(TIME) . boeing(ORG) closed down 1.8(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) and were flat post market . 

the u.s(GPE) .(GPE) federal aviation administration in late(DATE) january(DATE) barred boeing(ORG) from increasing production of the 737(PRODUCT) max as it presses for changes . 

on feb(DATE) .(DATE) 12(DATE) , faa(ORG) head mike(PERSON) whitaker(PERSON) visited boeing(ORG) ’s renton(GPE) , washington(GPE) , factory , where the 737(PRODUCT) max line is produced , and expressed concerns about some things he saw on the tour to ceo dave(PERSON) calhoun(PERSON) earlier(DATE) this(DATE) week(DATE) , two(CARDINAL) people briefed on the matter told reuters(ORG) .

spirit , one(CARDINAL) of the industry ’s major manufacturers of large aircraft structures , has struggled with cash flow problems over the(DATE) past(DATE) few(DATE) quarters(DATE) and quality issues surrounding the fuselages it makes for boeing(ORG) ’s 737(PRODUCT) narrowbody jets . 

the company is also exploring selling operations in ireland(GPE) that makes wings for the airbus(ORG) a220(PRODUCT) jet(PRODUCT) , as it would be unusual for boeing(ORG) to supply its competitor .

nepal - ranks-150th - in - ai - readiness - index : 

published on : march(DATE) 2(DATE) ,(DATE) 2024 04:25(TIME) pm(TIME) npt(PERSON) by : republica(PERSON) | @republicanepal 

kathmandu(GPE) , march(DATE) 2(DATE) : nepal has been ranked 150th(ORDINAL) out of 193(CARDINAL) countries in the government ai readiness index , 2023(DATE) . 

the report published by the oxford(ORG) insights shows the us in first(ORDINAL) position with 84.80(CARDINAL) total score , while singapore(GPE) the second(ORDINAL) in the index with 81.97(CARDINAL) total score . 

nepal(PERSON) has got the total score- 30.77(CARDINAL) . 

in the index , the total score is calculated from three(CARDINAL) bases- government pillar , technology sector pillar , and data and infrastructure pillar . 

with total score , 30.77(CARDINAL) , nepal(PERSON) has achieved 31.04(CARDINAL) in government pillar , 24.21(CARDINAL) in technology sector pillar , and 37.06(CARDINAL) in data and infrastructure pillar . 

in the(DATE) previous(DATE) year(DATE) , 2022(DATE) , nepal(PERSON) had secured 139th(ORG) position out of 181(CARDINAL) countries in the government ai readiness index . the total score was 30.75(CARDINAL) where nepal(GPE) got 30.88(CARDINAL) mark under government pillar , 23.50(CARDINAL) mark under technology sector pillar , and 37.88(CARDINAL) mark under the data and infrastructure pillar . 

afghanistan(GPE) has been ranked at the bottom ( 181st(NORP) rank ) with a 13.46(CARDINAL) total score in 2022(DATE) , while the(GPE) democratic(GPE) republic(GPE) of(GPE) korea(GPE) is at the bottom ( 193rd ) with a total score 9.20(CARDINAL) in 2023(DATE) . 

india(GPE) is ranked 40th(ORDINAL) while china(GPE) 16th(ORDINAL) in 2023(DATE) , while they were ranked 32nd(ORDINAL) and 17th(ORDINAL) respectively in 2022(DATE) . 

the three(CARDINAL) pillars were analyzed by setting different dimensions . under the government pillar , there were four(CARDINAL) dimensions- vision , governance and ethic , digital capacity , and adaptability . similarly , the technology sector pillar comprised three(CARDINAL) dimensions- maturity , innovation capacity , and human capital . the third(ORDINAL) pillar , data and infrastructure , has also included three(CARDINAL) dimensions , infrastructure , data availability and data representativeness . 

a total of 39(CARDINAL) indicators were set for 10(QUANTITY) dimensions(QUANTITY) under(QUANTITY) three(QUANTITY) pillars . 

the report collected data from various sources , including oecd(ORG) ai policy observatory , un(PERSON) idir(PERSON) ai(PERSON) policy portal , global cybersecurity index , worldwide governance indicators , un(ORG) e - government survey , network readiness index , international(ORG) telecommunications(ORG) union(ORG) , and the(ORG) world(ORG) bank(ORG) . 

the index has mentioned the developments relating to ai in all sorts of countries ranging from ldcs(GPE) to emerging economies to the developed ones . 

persisting global digital divide 

in the finding , the report stated , " half(CARDINAL) of the ai strategies that were published or announced come from low and lower middle - income countries . the scores in the data and infrastructure pillar show a substantial difference between high- and low - income economies , illustrating an existing global digital divide . " 

at a time when most of the countries are swayed by the modern buzz , ai , and striving to both promote and regulate ai irrespective of their capacities , the index is expected to cater relevant knowledge to the government , private sectors and researchers . 

the oxford(ORG) insights is a uk(GPE) - based organization working around the intersection of technology and government and generating global scale study reports .
