agalega(PERSON) - in - the - shifting - geopolitical - landscape : 

agalega(PERSON) in the shifting geopolitical landscape 

editorial 

for several(DATE) years(DATE) , the spectre of a clandestine mauritius(GPE) - india agreement to establish an indian(NORP) military base on agalega(PERSON) has loomed over parliamentary debates and local media headlines . the mere mention of a military base on this idyllic island in the indian(NORP) ocean has stirred controversy and raised concerns about sovereignty . yet , amidst the speculation and allegations , the mauritius government has consistently maintained a stance of denial , refuting the existence of any such agreement with the indian(NORP) authorities . 

as early as may 2017(DATE) , an official communique following prime minister pravind(PERSON) jugnauth(PERSON) ’s state visit to india(GPE) outlined plans for agalega(PERSON) ’s economic development . in this statement , it was revealed that basic infrastructure , including a runway and jetty , would be constructed by the(ORG) government(ORG) of(ORG) india(ORG) at its own expense . an agreement to this effect was signed during the prime minister ’s state visit , signalling india(GPE) ’s commitment to supporting mauritius in enhancing the economic potential of agalega(PERSON) . however , the authorities and the pmo steadfastly refused at making the mou(ORG) public or laying it in the national assembly , claiming a confidentiality clause , although india(GPE) was reported not to have any qualms on its public release . 

despite the pm ’s assurances therefore and the unexplained need for confidentiality , questions persisted , prompting further inquiries from both the public and political figures . notably , hon xavier duval raised concerns in may(DATE) 2021(DATE) , seeking clarity on the nature of the infrastructure projects and their implications for agalega(PERSON) ’s future . in response , the prime minister reiterated the collaborative nature of the projects , emphasizing that they aimed to bolster economic development rather than establish a military base . mention was made of mauritius(GPE) partnering india(GPE) in the latter ’s sagar project for regional development and security challenges in the north indian ocean . it was also categorically stated that there would be no stockpile of weapons on agalega(PERSON) , distinguishing it from conventional military bases established by other nations in the region . 

the most recent affirmation of mauritius(GPE) ’ sovereignty over agalega(PERSON) came from prime minister jugnauth(PERSON) during the inauguration of the newly constructed facilities on february(DATE) 29(DATE) . these projects , including a jetty and a three(QUANTITY) -(QUANTITY) kilometre(QUANTITY) - long runway , were fully financed and built by the indian(NORP) authorities . the prime minister reassured the public that mauritius(GPE) would retain control over these facilities , dispelling concerns about jeopardizing the island ’s sovereignty . 

while official statements seek to allay fears , there has been and remains a palpable need for greater openness from mauritian(GPE) and indian(NORP) authorities regarding the details of the bilateral agreement . the lack of transparency has fuelled speculation , some unhealthy or unproductive , in some(DATE) quarters(DATE) . clarity on the terms and conditions governing india(GPE) ’s generous contribution to the development of agalega(PERSON) ’s infrastructure is essential . 

on the other hand , amidst this controversy , it is crucial to analyze the shifting geopolitical dynamics in the indian(NORP) ocean region . the emergence of new players with diverse strategic interests , coupled with security challenges such as piracy and geopolitical tensions , underscores the importance of safeguarding mauritius ’ security and economic interests . as a small island state , mauritius(GPE) must navigate these complexities with foresight and strategic acumen . unfortunately , it has not developed a mature approach where political divides can be bridged for matters of national interest or where leaders of opposition parties can be taken in the confidence of what ’s brewing . 

in conclusion , while the agalega(PERSON) controversy continues to spark debate and speculation , it is imperative to separate fact from fiction and embrace geopolitical realities . transparent communication from the authorities , coupled with a nuanced understanding of regional geopolitics , is essential for safeguarding mauritius(GPE) ’ sovereignty and security in an ever - evolving geopolitical landscape . as mauritius(ORG) charts its course in the indian(NORP) ocean , strategic alignment with regional dynamics that serve the nation ’s interests remains paramount . by strategizing intelligently and embracing transparency , mauritius(GPE) can advance its long - term political and economic interests amidst the complexities of the indian(NORP) ocean region . 

mauritius(ORG) times(ORG) epaper friday(DATE) 1(DATE) march(DATE) 2024(DATE) 

an appeal 

dear reader 

65(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) mauritius times was founded with a resolve to fight for justice and fairness and the advancement of the public good . it has never deviated from this principle no matter how daunting the challenges and how costly the price it has had to pay at different times of our history . 

with print journalism struggling to keep afloat due to falling advertising revenues and the wide availability of free sources of information , it is crucially important for the mauritius times to survive and prosper . we can only continue doing it with the support of our readers . 

the best way you can support our efforts is to take a subscription or by making a recurring donation through a standing order to our non - profit foundation . 

thank you .

supreme - court - police - ip - warrant - canada : 

the(ORG) supreme(ORG) court(ORG) of(ORG) canada(ORG) ruled friday(DATE) that police must obtain a warrant before requesting a canadians(NORP) ’ internet protocol address in a significant victory for privacy advocates . 

in a 5(CARDINAL) - 4 ruling , the(ORG) supreme(ORG) court(ORG) asserted that canadians(NORP) have charter - protected privacy rights when it comes to cops requesting information about their online activities . 

“ personal privacy is vital to individual dignity , autonomy , and personal growth . its protection is a basic prerequisite to the flourishing of a free and healthy democracy , ” the majority ruling read . 

“ the internet requires that users reveal subscriber information to their isp to participate in this new public square , and canadians(NORP) are not required to become digital recluses in order to maintain some semblance of privacy in their lives . ” 

at issue was a 2017(DATE) investigation by the(ORG) calgary(ORG) police(ORG) into fraudulent online purchases from a liquor store . 

police went to the liquor store ’s payment processing company , moneris(PERSON) , and requested internet protocol ( ip ) addresses related to the purchases . they did not get a warrant . 

moneris(PERSON) handed over two(CARDINAL) ip addresses used for the transactions , which the police used to obtain a court order requiring an internet service provider to turn over the names and addresses associated with the ip addresses . 

that led to a search of andrei(ORG) bykovets(ORG) ’(ORG) residence(ORG) , and to bykovet(PERSON) ’s arrest on charges of possessing other peoples ’ credit cards and identification documents . bykovet(PERSON) challenged the cops ’ right to obtain his ip address from moneris(PERSON) , arguing it violated his charter rights against unreasonable search and seizure . 

both the trial judge and the(ORG) alberta(ORG) court(ORG) of appeal ruled that canadians(NORP) had no reasonable expectation of privacy for their ip address . the(ORG) supreme(ORG) court(ORG) disagreed . 

“ activity associated with the ip addresses can be correlated with other online activity associated with that address available to the state . an ip address can also set the state on a trail of internet activity that leads directly to a user ’s identity , ” the decision read . 

“ access to ip addresses without judicial pre - authorization poses intense privacy risks . ” 

police agencies used to routinely request what they called “ basic subscriber information ” from telecommunications companies – information such as names , ip addresses , physical addresses and telephone numbers . 

but the supreme(ORG) court(ORG) ruling does not stop police from accessing ip addresses – just requires them to get a court order first(ORDINAL) , a process that law enforcement agencies have said takes time particularly for urgent cases . 

the(ORG) bc(ORG) civil(ORG) liberties(ORG) association(ORG) , which intervened in the case , welcomed the court ’s majority decision friday(DATE) and said it was “ heartened ” by the court ’s recognition that privacy has become “ ever more important ” in the digital age . 

“ the reality today(DATE) is that in order to engage in society to any degree , we really have to be able to go online . and so if the police have easy access to all of our online activity , which website we ’re going to , who we ’re talking to online , that creates a huge chilling effect on people ’s behaviour , ” vibert(PERSON) jack(PERSON) , the bccla(GPE) ’s director of litigation , told global in an interview . 

“ privacy rights are obviously implicated , but our freedom of expression , freedom of association , those rights would all be curtailed if we know the police could be watching us while we ’re online . ” 

while the(ORG) supreme(ORG) court(ORG) decision notes that the determining a reasonable expectation of privacy under the charter is an “ exercise in balance , ” it also noted that the internet has vastly expanded the amount of personal information 

“ the intensely private nature of the information an ip address may betray strongly suggests that the public ’s interest in being left alone should prevail over the government ’s interest in advancing its law enforcement goals , ” the decision read .

james(ORG) -(ORG) hart(ORG) will join breast surgeon dr . trudi(PERSON) brown(PERSON) in april(DATE) , chan soon - shiong medical center at windber(ORG) announced in a press release . 

“ i am looking forward to joining the(ORG) joyce(ORG) murtha(ORG) breast(ORG) care(ORG) center(ORG) because it is clear to me that they value breast cancer care and breast health as their own entity as a science and service , ” james(ORG) -(ORG) hart(ORG) said . “ they understand that it is an essential service that women in the community need and deserve . 

“ education , prevention , treatment and survivorship are essential components of breast health and breast cancer . the center is committed to this concept , and i am proud to join their team . ” 

james(ORG) -(ORG) hart(ORG) has 27(DATE) years(DATE) of experience as a surgeon and has specialized in treatment of benign and malignant breast disease for most of her career . 

she performs breast biopsies as well as lumpectomies , mastectomies , nipple - sparing mastectomies and sentinel lymph node biopsies . 

a graduate of joan(ORG) c.(ORG) edwards(ORG) school of medicine at marshall(ORG) university(ORG) in huntington(GPE) , west(GPE) virginia(GPE) , james(ORG) -(ORG) hart(ORG) completed a general surgery residency at harlem(ORG) hospital(ORG) center(ORG) in new(GPE) york(GPE) , where she served as chief resident for pediatric surgery and surgery . she then pursued a surgical oncology fellowship at roswell(ORG) park(ORG) cancer institute in buffalo(GPE) ,(GPE) new(GPE) york(GPE) . 

her career began with a position in surgery with northern generations / health and hospitals(ORG) corp(ORG) .(ORG) , of new(GPE) york(GPE) , and continued with surgical positions in newport news , virginia(GPE) , and charleston(GPE) and beckley(GPE) , west(GPE) virginia(GPE) . 

in 2011(DATE) , she established a practice focused on breast care at women ’s and children ’s hospital in lafayette(GPE) , louisiana(GPE) . 

most recently , james(ORG) -(ORG) hart(ORG) served as a breast surgeon and surgical oncologist with upmc(PERSON) altoona(PERSON) . 

she is certified by the(ORG) american(ORG) board(ORG) of surgery and is an active member of the(ORG) national(ORG) medical(ORG) association(ORG) , the american(NORP) society of breast surgeons and the society of surgical oncology . 

james(ORG) -(ORG) hart(ORG) will become the fourth(ORDINAL) breast surgeon to practice at the(FAC) joyce(FAC) murtha(FAC) breast(FAC) care(FAC) center(FAC) since it opened in 2002(DATE) . 

founding breast surgeon dr . dianna(PERSON) craig(PERSON) resigned in september(DATE) 2014(DATE) , taking a similar position with upmc(ORG) altoona(ORG) . that prompted the hiring of sims in october(DATE) 2014(DATE) . brown(PERSON) joined the local breast center in september(DATE) 2018(DATE) .

us - asylum - measure - aimed - at - curbing - claims - has - limited - impact - given - strained - border - budget : 

us asylum measure aimed at curbing claims has limited impact given strained border budget 

tucson(GPE) , ariz . ( ap ) — inside giant white tents that house about(CARDINAL) 1,000(CARDINAL) migrants near tucson(FAC) international(FAC) airport(FAC) , border patrol agents demonstrate clockwork efficiency to release detainees within two(DATE) days(DATE) of arrest with orders to appear in immigration courts at their final destinations . agents transmit information from the field to colleagues who prepare court papers while migrants are bused hours(TIME) away to a processing center , minimizing time in custody . 

notably missing from the operations hub in the busiest corridor for illegal crossings into the u.s(GPE) .(GPE) are asylum officers who do initial screenings , which are intended to weed out weak claims that do n't meet narrowly prescribed grounds for seeking protection , such as race , religion and political opinion . 

asylum officers were instructed nearly(DATE) a(DATE) year(DATE) ago(DATE) to apply a higher screening standard on those who cross the border illegally after passing though another country , such as mexico(GPE) , but they are too understaffed to have much impact . the biden administration hails the higher standard as a cornerstone of its border policy in legal challenges , but its application in only a small percentage of arrests shows how budgets can fail to match ambitions . 

strained budgets continue to loom large as the(ORG) white(ORG) house(ORG) again considers sweeping measures to limit asylum at the border . 

the failure of a $(MONEY) 20(MONEY) billion(MONEY) spending plan on border security this(DATE) month(DATE) has caused the administration to assess its priorities . u.s(GPE) .(GPE) immigration and customs enforcement , facing a $(MONEY) 700(MONEY) million(MONEY) hole this(DATE) year(DATE) , is considering cutting the number of detention beds from 38,000(CARDINAL) to 22,000(CARDINAL) and facilitating fewer deportation flights . these possible steps were first(ORDINAL) reported by the washington(GPE) post and confirmed to the associated press by a u.s(GPE) .(GPE) official who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it publicly . 

the failed spending package crafted by senate(ORG) negotiators would have given $(MONEY) 4(MONEY) billion(MONEY) to u.s(GPE) .(GPE) citizenship and immigration services , including to add 4,338(CARDINAL) asylum officers to screen applicants and make final decisions on claims — more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) four(CARDINAL) times current staffing . 

arrests for illegal border crossings from mexico(GPE) plunged to the second(ORDINAL) - lowest monthly(DATE) rate of joe(PERSON) biden(PERSON) 's(PERSON) presidency , a(DATE) month(DATE) after the higher standard replaced covid-19 pandemic - related asylum restrictions . the rule “ is working as intended and has already significantly reduced encounters at the border , ” blas(PERSON) nuñez - neto , assistant homeland security secretary for border and immigration policy , said in a court filing at the time . 

asylum - seekers subject to tougher screenings had a 59(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) pass rate through september(DATE) , down from 85(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) in the(DATE) five(DATE) years(DATE) before the pandemic , nuñez - neto said in another court filing . 

while that suggests the policy has made a difference , its scope has been limited . officers interviewed only(CARDINAL) 57,700(CARDINAL) migrants under the new rule through september(DATE) , according to nuñez - neto . that represents only(PERCENT) about(PERCENT) 15(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) of the nearly(CARDINAL) 365,500(CARDINAL) migrants released by border patrol from june(DATE) to(DATE) september(DATE) with notices to appear in immigration court . 

the(ORG) department(ORG) of(ORG) homeland(ORG) security(ORG) declined to provide more recent numbers . it insists the higher screening standard is working as intended , while acknowledging it has failed to keep pace with unprecedented migration flows and calling on congress(ORG) to adequately fund the efforts . 

asylum officers did more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 130,000(CARDINAL) screenings , known as “ credible fear interviews , ” at the border during the 2023(DATE) budget(DATE) year(DATE) , which was more than double the(DATE) year(DATE) before(DATE) . but more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 600,000(CARDINAL) migrants were released with notices to appear in immigration court in that time and another 300,000(CARDINAL) with orders to report to an immigration office for a court date , a practice that has largely ceased . 

the border patrol released mbala(PERSON) giodi(PERSON) , 42(DATE) , after holding him for two(DATE) days(DATE) when he crossed the border in remote mountains east of san(GPE) diego(GPE) . he was dropped off at a transit center and told he would have a chance to explain his case for asylum in court , with an initial hearing scheduled in new(GPE) york(GPE) in may . 

“ there was n’t much problem , ” said giodi(GPE) , 42(DATE) , who calls himself a victim of government repression for being a student protestor in angola(GPE) . 

to put the higher screening standard into effect , citizenship and immigration services added about(CARDINAL) 1,000(CARDINAL) staff to assist an existing 850(CARDINAL) or so asylum officers , training former asylum officers and other employees for short stints , said michael(PERSON) knowles(PERSON) , spokesman for the national citizenship and immigration(ORG) services(ORG) council(ORG) . the union represents workers at the agency , which also oversees work visas , green cards , citizenship applications and asylum claims that originate away from the border . 

assigning so many employees to border cases extended waits for other services , he said . weekend(DATE) overtime was mandatory , as was holiday work . 

“ we ’re so overwhelmed and there ’s so much pressure , ” knowles said . “ part of the border crisis is they did n’t hire enough of us to do the work . ” 

a lack of resources hampered another biden policy that took effect in june(DATE) 2022(DATE) , empowering asylum officers to make final rulings on claims , not just screenings . it aimed to ease the workload of immigration judges , whose backlog of more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 3(CARDINAL) million(CARDINAL) cases has allowed asylum - seekers with weak claims to stay in the(GPE) united(GPE) states(GPE) for years(DATE) — with eligibility for work permits — while their cases wind through the system . 

fewer(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 6,000(CARDINAL) asylum cases had been decided under the 2022(DATE) policy by the(DATE) end(DATE) of(DATE) september(DATE) . 

“ that is a very important program that got very little support , ” knowles said . 

advocates for asylum - seekers have sued over application of the higher screening standard . they argue it unfairly penalizes those who cross the border illegally while a heavily oversubscribed online appointment system , called cbp(ORG) one(ORG) , is virtually the only way to come through an official port of entry . the standard remains in effect while a judge 's ruling declaring the policy illegal is under appeal . 

while migration flows dropped immediately after the higher standard took effect , border steady increased as migrants and smugglers adjusted to realities on the ground , peaking at an all - time high of 250,000(CARDINAL) in december(DATE) . 

melissa(PERSON) crow , director of litigation at the center for gender & refugee studies , which is challenging the higher standard , said asylum - seekers eventually face tougher scrutiny before a judge even if the rule ’s limited use at the border allows them to avoid screening . and , she said , congress(ORG) and the(ORG) white(ORG) house(ORG) may agree in the future to provide more money .

kentucky(GPE) - legislature - school - bus - safety-0cb3c3d82ca7160cdf801b0b961e5dcf : 

kentucky(ORG) house(ORG) passes legislation aimed at curbing unruliness on school buses 

frankfort(ORG) , ky . ( ap(PERSON) ) — the kentucky(GPE) house passed a bill friday(DATE) aimed at curbing unruliness on school buses by requiring student and parental buy - in to transportation policies and setting clear consequences for misbehavior . 

the measure sailed through the house on a 93(CARDINAL) - 1 vote to advance to the senate(ORG) . supporters said the goal is to offer relief to beleaguered bus drivers by setting expectations for students and parents . 

misbehavor(ORG) on school buses was termed a statewide issue , but the house discussion focused on kentucky(GPE) ’s largest school system , in louisville(GPE) . in november(DATE) the district was forced to cancel nearly(CARDINAL) 100(CARDINAL) routes after bus drivers organized a sickout and 143(CARDINAL) called off work , with student behavior cited as among their biggest concerns , the courier journal of louisville(GPE) reported . 

setting accountability is crucial to getting the problem under control , republican(ORG) rep(ORG) . kevin(PERSON) bratcher(PERSON) said . 

“ accountability — what happens when you get so far out of line that you ’re stopping a school bus from operating , ” he said . “ you ’re causing the school bus driver to quit their job . ” 

the bill would require local school boards statewide to adopt a policy outlining what ’s expected of students riding school buses and the consequences for failing to meet those standards . 

“ drivers have a huge responsibility , and we should respect and address concerns thoroughly , ” said republican(ORG) rep(ORG) . emily(PERSON) callaway(PERSON) , the bill ’s lead sponsor . 

in setting guidelines , boards would work off a model policy developed by the(ORG) state(ORG) education(ORG) department(ORG) . 

students and parents would have to sign a document acknowledging the policy each(DATE) school(DATE) year(DATE) , and failure to do so could be grounds for revoking bus - riding privileges . 

each district ’s policy would also establish procedures for investigating complaints and protecting those who bring them from retaliation . severe or repeated misconduct could also lead to a loss of bus - riding privileges . 

“ we must be sure that if a student puts him or herself , other riders or the driver in danger , the driver can act appropriately , swiftly and effectively , ” callaway(ORG) said . “ this policy allows for that discretion . ” 

district policies would provide for expeditious reviews of driver complaints about student misbehavior , and drivers would be allowed to be heard during disciplinary procedures . they must also be notified of the outcome of disciplinary actions . if a driver continues to feel unsafe transporting a student , the driver would be allowed to opt out of transporting that student . 

_ _ _ 

the legislation is house bill 446(CARDINAL) .

sky network television insider transactions over the(DATE) last(DATE) year(DATE) 

in the(DATE) last(DATE) twelve(DATE) months(DATE) , the biggest single purchase by an insider was when insider philip(PERSON) bowman(PERSON) bought nz$537k worth of shares at a price of nz$2.70 per share . so it 's clear an insider wanted to buy , at around the current price , which is nz$2.77 . of course they may have changed their mind . but this suggests they are optimistic . while we always like to see insider buying , it 's less meaningful if the purchases were made at much lower prices , as the opportunity they saw may have passed . the good news for sky network television share holders is that insiders were buying at near the current price .

insider ownership of sky network television 

another way to test the alignment between the leaders of a company and other shareholders is to look at how many shares they own . a high insider ownership often makes company leadership more mindful of shareholder interests . based on our data , sky network television insiders have about(PERCENT) 0.7(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) of the stock , worth approximately nz$2.8 m. we consider this fairly low insider ownership . 

so what does this data suggest about sky network television insiders ? 

the recent insider purchase is heartening . we also take confidence from the longer term picture of insider transactions . while the overall levels of insider ownership are below what we 'd like to see , the history of transactions imply that sky network television insiders are reasonably well aligned , and optimistic for the future . so these insider transactions can help us build a thesis about the stock , but it 's also worthwhile knowing the risks facing this company . to that end , you should learn about the 2(CARDINAL) warning signs we 've spotted with sky network television ( including 1(CARDINAL) which is a bit concerning ) .

fps - approves-2 - new - schools - focused - on - self - directed - learning - mental - health : 

fargo(ORG) public(ORG) schools(ORG) approves 2(CARDINAL) new schools focused on self - directed learning , mental health 

the(ORG) fargo(ORG) school(ORG) board(ORG) approved the schools , which will be established in existing buildings . 

fargo(GPE) — the(ORG) fargo(ORG) school(ORG) board(ORG) has voted to establish two(CARDINAL) new academic models or “ schools ” in the district — one(CARDINAL) prioritizing individualized learning and the other mental health . 

during its tuesday(DATE) ,(DATE) feb(DATE) .(DATE) 27(DATE) meeting , the board unanimously approved a self - directed academy and a mental health therapeutic school at explorer(ORG) academy(ORG) , with both starting this(DATE) fall(DATE) . 

superintendent rupak(PERSON) gandhi(PERSON) said the first(ORDINAL) is an innovative approach to benefit students who may underperform in a traditional setting , while the second(ORDINAL) will prioritize students ' mental health while providing them an education . 

the self - directed academy will initially be for grades six(CARDINAL) through eight , and later k-8(GPE) . 

it will first(ORDINAL) be housed at the fps agassiz building at 1305(DATE) 9th(DATE) ave(DATE) . s.(PERSON) , gandhi(PERSON) said , with hopes that the district ’s current long - range facilities planning will identify a future , permanent site . 

advertisement 

the academy is not a hybrid or virtual model , and students will have to meet the same standards as those in the traditional setting but at their own pace . 

“ all of the instruction in this building is still in person . it 's just not bound by time , ” gandhi(PERSON) said . 

a team of five(CARDINAL) or(CARDINAL) six(CARDINAL) educators , including student teachers , paraprofessionals and certified teachers , will be assigned to between(CARDINAL) 100(CARDINAL) to(CARDINAL) 120(CARDINAL) students . the academy could grow to as(CARDINAL) many(CARDINAL) as(CARDINAL) 400(CARDINAL) students , with staff increasing accordingly , he said . 

students will be transported by shuttle from their home middle school campus to the academy and back at the end of the school day for any activities they ’re involved in , he said . 

though the concept was unanimously approved , board members and fargo(ORG) education(ORG) association(ORG) president grant kraft had plenty of concerns and questions beforehand . 

kraft said educators have asked him how staffing will work , and whether staff transfers will be voluntary or involuntary . 

gandhi(PERSON) said he anticipates some current staff will apply and the district may need to make new hires . 

board member katie(PERSON) christianson(PERSON) expressed concern that enrollment will decline in traditional middle schools if many students move to the academy . 

advertisement 

she wondered whether specialized programs like foreign languages or music could then be affected . 

“ i do n't view this as a threat to our comprehensive schools , ” gandhi(PERSON) said . 

academy to follow arizona(GPE) model 

the school district made its first(ORDINAL) official step toward a self - directed academy when the board gave administration the go - ahead to begin exploring and planning the idea last(DATE) september(DATE) . 

the action also allowed the district to submit an innovation waiver to the(ORG) state(ORG) department(ORG) of(ORG) public(ORG) instruction(ORG) . 

gandhi(PERSON) said he ’s confident the department will grant the waiver , allowing the district to start enrolling students in the academy . 

the academy will follow the next education workforce model developed by arizona(ORG) state(ORG) university(ORG) ’s mary(PERSON) lou(PERSON) fulton(PERSON) teachers college . 

several fps administrators traveled to arizona(GPE) last(DATE) fall(DATE) to learn more about it , and several more will go in a(DATE) few(DATE) weeks(DATE) , gandhi(PERSON) said . 

the academy fits in with one(CARDINAL) of the district ’s strategic initiatives calling for “ continuous improvement ” for students with disparate outcomes . 

advertisement 

in a traditional school model , teachers must embed state standards in a school calendar and follow a pacing schedule of when to introduce new material to students . 

students who are regularly absent or more mobile , transferring in or out of a district , will miss certain instruction . 

when assessed later , they might underperform not because they do n't have the ability to show proficiency but solely because they were n’t there , gandhi(PERSON) said . 

the academy is modeled after a school in wilder , idaho(GPE) that serves primarily migrant communities with high mobility rates . 

“ it 's been wildly successful and it 's been a model that we 've thought would be very successful for some of our students , ” gandhi(PERSON) said . 

mental health prioritized 

at the tuesday(DATE) meeting , the board also unanimously approved establishment of a mental health therapeutic school to be located at explorer(ORG) academy(ORG) , the district ’s k-8(ORG) special(ORG) education(ORG) school(ORG) at 1780(DATE) 17th(DATE) st(DATE) . s.(PERSON) 
(PERSON)
while the primary purpose of explorer(ORG) academy(ORG) wo n’t change , part of the building will be used for the non - public , day treatment center , a board memo said . 

a partnering agency , specializing in therapeutic mental health services , will run the treatment center , with fargo public schools being the exclusive provider of academic instruction . 

advertisement 

as a public entity governed by the(ORG) department(ORG) of(ORG) public(ORG) instruction(ORG) , the district is limited to k-12(ORG) academics(ORG) , gandhi(PERSON) said , and ca n’t bill a family ’s insurance plan for services provided , for example . 

“ we ca n't be a treatment provider because we 're educators and not healthcare providers , so this is an avenue to partner together with a health care provider to bridge that gap , ” he said . 

a non - public school can prioritize therapeutic treatment and schedule academics around that treatment , rather than dictate a majority of time be spent on academics , he added . 

after some board members expressed concerns about the arrangement of operating a non - public school within a public school , gandhi(PERSON) assured them that the dpi presented the idea as a viable option . 

he also said it will be a similar set up to the school district 's agreement with nexus - path 's luther(PERSON) hall(PERSON) , a residential treatment facility for boys and girls ages 10(CARDINAL) -(CARDINAL) 17(CARDINAL) , where fps provides academic instruction . 

the district expects to start hearing proposals from organizations interested in operating the mental health therapeutic school starting march(DATE) 6(DATE) .

how - humans - lost - their - tails - and - why - the - discovery - took-2 - 5 - years - to - publish.html : 

ewen(PERSON) callaway(PERSON) in nature : 

geneticist bo(PERSON) xia(PERSON) asked that question as a child and it was on his mind again a(DATE) few(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) , while he was recovering from a tailbone injury during his phd at new(ORG) york(ORG) university(ORG) ( nyu(ORG) ) in new(GPE) york(GPE) city(GPE) . xia(PERSON) and his colleagues now have an answer . the researchers identified a genetic change shared by humans and other apes that might have contributed to their ancestors ’ tail loss , some(DATE) 25(DATE) million(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) . mice carrying similar alterations to their genomes had short or absent tails , the researchers found — but that insight was hard won . the work was published on 28(CARDINAL) february1(WORK_OF_ART) : nearly(DATE) 900(DATE) days(DATE) after being submitted to nature and posted as a preprint , because of extra work needed to develop several strains of gene - edited mice and demonstrate that the genetic changes had the predicted effect . 

“ respect to the authors , ” says malte(PERSON) spielmann(PERSON) , a human geneticist at kiel(ORG) university(ORG) in germany(GPE) , who reviewed the paper for nature . “ i ’m incredibly excited about the fact that they ’ve really pulled it off . ” 

the mice with no tails 

unlike most monkeys , apes — including humans — and their close extinct relatives do n’t have tails . their coccyx , or tailbone , is a vestige of the vertebrae that constitute a tail in other animals . finding the genetic basis for this trait was n’t what xia , now at the broad institute of mit and harvard(ORG) in cambridge(GPE) , massachusetts(GPE) , planned to devote his phd to . but his coccyx injury , sustained during a cab ride , reinvigorated his tail curiosity .

we - have - suffered - too - much - friday(DATE) - protests - continue - in - kafr - qaduum : 

1(DATE) march(DATE) 2024(DATE) | international solidarity movement | kafr(PERSON) qaduum(PERSON) 
(PERSON)
it is friday(DATE) , and the call to prayer is heard in the rural village of kafr(GPE) qaduum(GPE) , west of nablus(GPE) in the northern part of the(GPE) west(GPE) bank(GPE) . the streets are quiet , empty except some children playing and a few cars heading early to the masjid . around 11 am , some men and boys gather and drink coffee off the main road next door . younger children play and laugh . the scene appears calm if expectant , with an underlying tension . like every friday , after prayer , villagers march in protest of the closure of their village ’s main road and against the israeli(NORP) occupation . 

protests are a regular part of life in rural villages across palestine(GPE) – some as far back as the second(ORDINAL) intifada . but in most parts of the west(GPE) bank(GPE) unarmed protest marches left off after october(DATE) 7th(DATE) , when soldiers and settlers took advantage of hamas(ORG) ’ attacks to unleash a wave of violence , terrorism , land and resource theft against their palestinian(NORP) neighbors . while before , the military used principally tear gas , sound bombs , and rubber coated steel bullets to disperse protestors , since the 7th(ORDINAL) villagers of kafr(ORG) qaduum(ORG) report encountering exclusively live gunfire . 

israeli(NORP) drone flying over the protestors . @ism 

but protests in kafr(GPE) qaduum(GPE) never stopped . abu(PERSON) masseib(PERSON) , former mayor of the village , proudly states they have marched for the opening of their main road every(DATE) friday(DATE) for 13(DATE) years(DATE) – ever since the israeli(NORP) courts refused to uphold their rights . he reports that while military aggression has made protesting more dangerous , the villagers have persisted , adapting their practices to minimize harm . fewer villagers go out each(DATE) week(DATE) , they move cautiously and report back and withdraw quickly if military movements are observed . in spite of these precautions , masseib(ORG) reports that the military have caused serious injuries . since 2011(DATE) , he states that over(CARDINAL) 100(CARDINAL) villagers have been shot with live ammunition . over(CARDINAL) 150(CARDINAL) were arrested , he says , for weeks(DATE) to as long as a year . while none have died , 2(CARDINAL) children suffered horrifying brain injuries from “ less lethal ” rounds to the head . just(DATE) last(DATE) week(DATE) a youth was shot in the face , but survived when the bullet rebounded into his jaw . many more villagers have lost eyes or suffered serious injuries to legs or stomach . in a group of 14(CARDINAL) palestinian(NORP) youths and adults sitting with us , he says “ 10(CARDINAL) of us have been shot with live [ ammunition ] ” . 

when asked why he thinks the people of kafr(GPE) qaduum(GPE) continue to protest when other villages have paused marches , he says , “ we had this issue before oct(DATE) 7th(DATE) ; we want a free road . we have suffered too much ; we understand the occupation . ” over(PERCENT) 50(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) of the village is in area c – parts of the(GPE) west(GPE) bank(GPE) annexed by israel(GPE) , made available for israeli(NORP) settlement and off limits to palestinians(NORP) . this includes most of the villagers ’ olive trees , their primary agricultural production and of immense symbolic value . “ it hurts all the people of the village , ” abu(ORG) maseib(ORG) says . 

today(DATE) the military presence is mostly hidden . a low flying drone watches overhead , and four(CARDINAL) soldiers ’ helmets and hair peek out over the closest hill . the protest moves conservatively , quietly , without shouted slogans or flung stones . still the palestine red crescent ambulance and media are ready to respond and document military aggression . the protest ends abruptly when report comes of military movements , and we — the only internationals present – are shuttled safely out of town before anything escalates . 

it is hard to guess whether solidarity(ORG) activist presence acts as a deterrent these(DATE) days(DATE) . indeed , organizer murad(PERSON) shtaiwi(PERSON) reports there have n’t been other solidarity(ORG) activists present since october(DATE) 7th(DATE) . villagers worry about exposing outsiders to the level of violence they themselves experience on a weekly(DATE) and sometimes daily(DATE) basis . murad(PERSON) reports that much of the violence occurs during the(DATE) week(DATE) , when soldiers enter the village to damage property , arrest protestors identified in drone photos , or just fire guns indiscriminately . he shares a phone video that clearly shows soldiers firing their weapons at head height and up into residential buildings . these are not shots intended only to frighten or disperse , but to injure and kill . 

before solidarity(ORG) activists are driven away , everyone walks together back to the relative safety of home . murad(PERSON) affirms that this is good timing . “ it is an honor , ” he says , “ for us to have martyrs ; but it is a greater honor to have living children ” .

article-789656 : 

since the israel(GPE) - hamas war broke out , we have witnessed israel(GPE) ’s long arm of counter - terrorism operations ( at least those we read about ) , such as the assassination of a hamas(ORG) leader with a well - placed rocket through a window , and a raid into a palestinian(NORP) hospital . unlike the aerial assassination , the hospital raid required boots in the hallways . 

the bravery of the idf(PRODUCT) , shin bet , and police yamam counter - terrorism squads is unmatched . yet both of these events reminded me in some respects of the death of another terrorist in october(DATE) 1995(DATE) – fathi shikaki , the leader of palestine(ORG) islamic(ORG) jihad(ORG) ( pij(ORG) ) . 

in april(DATE) of(DATE) that(DATE) year(DATE) , my 20(DATE) -(DATE) year(DATE) -(DATE) old(DATE) daughter , alisa(PERSON) , was riding on a bus near the jewish(NORP) community of kfar(ORG) darom(ORG) in gaza(GPE) . alisa(PERSON) was on what she thought would be a three(DATE) -(DATE) day(DATE) vacation before passover . in a phone call to me while waiting for her bus in jerusalem(GPE) , which would be the first(ORDINAL) leg of her journey , she told me she “ wanted to get a(DATE) few(DATE) days(DATE) in the sun ” before the holiday . it would be the last time we spoke . 

she never completed that bus journey because a van parked alongside the road outside the gates to kfar(ORG) darom(ORG) suddenly sped from the shoulder of the road and struck the bus on its right side . the driver then ignited a massive bomb packed inside the van . 

pij(ORG) took credit for the attack in a series of messages relayed to the media and to a college professor in the(GPE) united(GPE) states(GPE) . ( i would learn later that pij did not act alone ; the bomb was made by hamas(ORG) ’s master bomber , yayha(PERSON) ayyash(PERSON) , “ the engineer , ” who himself would be assassinated in early(DATE) 1996(DATE) . ) 

it was a friday(DATE) afternoon(TIME) in october(DATE) that same year when shikaki stepped out of a hotel on the(LOC) mediterranean(LOC) island(LOC) of malta(GPE) . two(CARDINAL) men on a motorcycle stopped opposite him and shot him at point - blank range . while no one took credit for the attack , it was conveyed to me by a caller that i might take some sense of justice delivered from the death of this man . my understanding was that shikaki ’s death was carried out by israel(GPE) ’s long arm of retribution – think post - munich massacre . and the murder of alisa(PERSON) and seven(CARDINAL) others at kfar(ORG) darom(ORG) was worthy of an effort to track down and eliminate the head of pij(ORG) . 

word of the assassination and its link to alisa(PERSON) ’s murder resulted in my being interviewed by a new(GPE) york(GPE) city(GPE) news station . i must have looked like a deer in the headlights when asked for my feelings about shikaki ’s death ; all i could think of saying was “ i am not going to sit shiva for him . ” 

other terrorists have died at the hands of the idf(PRODUCT) , and i am sure israeli(NORP) agents . blame for the drone attack that killed one(CARDINAL) of hamas(ORG) ’s senior leaders , saleh(PERSON) al(PERSON) -(PERSON) arouri(PERSON) , was quickly placed by hamas(ORG) supporters at israel(GPE) ’s feet . 

the social media response was interesting . a general strike was called in the palestinian(NORP) authority territory in the(GPE) west(GPE) bank(GPE) , his mother was grateful he died as a martyr , his “ hope , ” she said . a video was posted , allegedly showing an idf(NORP) soldier handing out candy , as is frequently done in palestinian(NORP) areas when israelis(NORP) are murdered in terror attacks . 

it ’s the comments from the(ORG) pro(ORG) -(ORG) israel(ORG) side that got me thinking about the issue i raise . from a limited reading of coverage in israeli(NORP) media , i came across these comments : “ whoever did the bombing , may they be more successful bombing the rest of the leadership of iran(GPE) , ” “ it ’s a good day when terrorists die , ” “ what good news . more please . ” “ wonderful news , just delightful – and long overdue . ” and “ mazal(PERSON) tov(PERSON) . ” 

what should we feel when a terrorist dies ? 

so , what are we supposed to feel when someone responsible for the deaths of israeli(NORP) civilians meets his own end ? 

many(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) , i was puzzled by the different hallel we say on the(DATE) first(DATE) day(DATE) of passover ( two(DATE) days(DATE) in the diaspora ) and on hol(PERSON) hamoed – the(DATE) intermediate(DATE) days(DATE) of(DATE) the(DATE) holiday(DATE) . hallel , praises to god , is 18(CARDINAL) paragraphs , but on hol(PERSON) hamoed passover it ’s shortened to 10(CARDINAL) paragraphs . however , on sukkot(GPE) , the full hallel is recited each day of the holiday . i am not the only person who has asked why there is a difference ; the question has been discussed for centuries(DATE) . 

taking a legalistic approach to the differences , on sukkot the number of sacrifices offered in the temple set forth separately in the torah(PERSON) . think of each(DATE) day(DATE) as a separate holiday deserving its own obligation to recite hallel . on passover , however , the torah(PERSON) says about the sacrifices , “ similarly shall you do each day for seven(DATE) days(DATE) . ” in the words of rabbi basil herring , “ it is as if each day of passover is merely an extension of the first(ORDINAL) ” and therefore do not require the recital of the full hallel . 

there is also a spiritual approach . 

the talmud relates the children of israel(GPE) crossing through the sea of reeds and assembling on the other side . moses composed a song ; miriam(PERSON) did , too ; and the children of israel(GPE) were joyful about the drowning of the egyptians(NORP) in the sea . 

in addition , the talmud relates that the heavenly angels also began to sing praises , when a heavenly voice thunders and says , “ stop your celebration , the egyptians(NORP) are my children , too . ” while a full hallel is appropriate on the first(ORDINAL) day(s ) of passover , in commemoration of that voice we diminish our joy of the holiday by saying a shorter version during hol(PERSON) hamoed . 

when the almighty punishes murderers , we can rejoice but not by jumping for joy or extending a mazal(PERSON) tov(PERSON) to the idf(PRODUCT) . instead , we find our thanks in the hallel in both the full of the(DATE) first(DATE) days(DATE) of passover and the half(CARDINAL) of hol(ORG) hamoed and the(DATE) days(DATE) at the(DATE) end(DATE) of(DATE) the(DATE) holiday(DATE) . as despicable and vile that terrorists such as fathi shikaki , yahya ayash , and saleh(PERSON) al(PERSON) -(PERSON) arouri(PERSON) were , we should not celebrate their deaths . heaven does n’t want us to . 

the writer is the president of the religious zionists of america ( rza ) . he is the father of alisa(PERSON) flatow(PERSON) , who was murdered in an iranian(NORP) - sponsored palestinian(NORP) terrorist attack in 1995(DATE) , and author of a father ’s story : my fight for justice against iranian(NORP) terror . 

note : the rza is not affiliated with any american(NORP) or israeli(NORP) political party .

" the group takes financial controls and it security extremely seriously and is currently conducting a group - wide review of all systems and processes to secure the business more robustly going forward , " it said in the press release .

i - wish - i - had - never - come - to - the - uk - palestinian - academic - despairs - of - getting - visas - for - family - stuck - in -(GPE) gaza(GPE) : 

when bassem(PERSON) abudagga(PERSON) heard in 2022(DATE) that he had won a british(NORP) council scholarship to do his phd in britain(GPE) , he was elated . “ i was so proud , ” he recalls . “ it is what every academic in palestine(GPE) hopes for : to gain a qualification from the uk(GPE) . 

“ it felt like a turning point for my career , my future , my family . it would shift my prospects to a completely different place . ” 

full of optimism , abudagga(ORG) , a lecturer in business studies at al(ORG) -(ORG) azhar(ORG) university(ORG) in gaza(GPE) , which has since been destroyed by israeli(NORP) bombardment , arrived in the uk(GPE) that october(DATE) to take up his place at york(GPE) st john university . his scholarship is one(CARDINAL) of many awarded annually(DATE) under a prestigious scheme run by the(ORG) british(ORG) council(ORG) to build the capacity of palestinian(NORP) universities . “ this was a british(NORP) investment in me and in my country , ” he says . 

abudagga(PERSON) ’s only regret was that he would have to live apart for long periods from his wife , marim(PERSON) , and two(CARDINAL) children , karim(PERSON) , now four(CARDINAL) , and talya , nine(CARDINAL) . while the whole family could have applied for visas to accompany abudagga(PERSON) , the(ORG) british(ORG) council(ORG) made clear it could only cover the costs for him alone . it would have been too expensive for them all to leave gaza(GPE) , but it would be for the best in the long run , they believed . 

almost(DATE) a(DATE) year(DATE) and(DATE) a(DATE) half(DATE) later(DATE) , the pride and excitement have long gone , and abudagga(PERSON) is desperate . he wishes he had never come here . “ at the beginning , i was so happy , ” he tells the observer . “ now i am just full of regret , that i am not with my family , when they are in such danger . ” 

his wife and children are trapped in gaza(GPE) , in acute and constant danger , living in increasingly desperate conditions . every(DATE) day(DATE) he calls them on malfunctioning phone lines to hear the latest harrowing news of food and water shortages , illness , bombing and destruction , and the loss of friends . 

if that is not painful enough , abudagga(PERSON) faces another unequal challenge : confronting the same uk(GPE) authorities that were so keen to welcome him here just two(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) , in the hope of persuading them to help him bring his family to safety . 

the authorities have told him repeatedly that before they can get the visa application process off the ground , his wife must have fingerprints taken in gaza(GPE) and fill out the necessary forms . the only trouble is , abudagga(PERSON) says , there are no facilities left to get fingerprinting done in gaza(GPE) – no communication system , no help , no infrastructure . so it is impossible to complete this first(ORDINAL) set of tasks before being able to cross the border to egypt(GPE) to complete the application process . 

as one(CARDINAL) british(NORP) source put it : “ there are uk families and people with uk(GPE) relatives getting out . so it can be done . you have to wonder how much of this is to do with the uk(GPE) not wanting to give visas to palestinians(NORP) . ” 

on the(TIME) morning(TIME) of 7 october(DATE) last(DATE) year(DATE) , marim(PERSON) rang her husband from the family ’s home in abasan(GPE) , near khan(PERSON) younis(PERSON) , and told him of the hamas(ORG) attacks , in which more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 1,300(CARDINAL) israelis(NORP) had been murdered . “ she said ‘ we are now in a conflict zone ’ , ” he recalls . “ i knew from that moment that i had to get my family out and bring them here . the rules are clear that they are eligible to come to the uk(GPE) to be with me . i was very frightened , very afraid . ” 

since then , marim and the two(CARDINAL) children have moved five(CARDINAL) times as the israeli(NORP) assaults have intensified and spread . two(DATE) weeks(DATE) ago(DATE) , karim(PERSON) became ill and it was a desperate struggle to find medicine . 

marim(ORG) , talya and karim are currently living inside the(ORG) european(ORG) hospital(ORG) in khan(GPE) younis(GPE) , near rafah , the town that is under threat of imminent israeli(NORP) attack . “ my son became traumatised and depressed by the sound of the carpet bombing , ” says abudagga(PERSON) . “ i would ring them and i would hear it in the background all the time . the hospital is so big it is the only place where he can not hear the sound of the bombing . ” 

his case has been taken up by labour mps(PERSON) rachael(PERSON) maskell(PERSON) , the member for york(ORG) central(ORG) , and rebecca(PERSON) long(PERSON) bailey(PERSON) , who represents salford(PRODUCT) and eccles , where abudagga(PERSON) lives and lectures part time . 

maskell(ORG) said : “ through the(ORG) british(ORG) council(ORG) , the uk(GPE) government invited mr abudagga(PERSON) to the uk as an academic to study . his family could have resided with him . they now have a duty to support his family to be reunited safely with him . ” 

long bailey said : “ this is an urgent and harrowing situation . the government must establish an emergency family reunion visa scheme for desperate families impacted like this . ” 

a foreign office spokesman said : “ the safety of british(NORP) nationals is our top priority . we have helped more(CARDINAL) than(CARDINAL) 300(CARDINAL) british(NORP) nationals and their dependants to leave gaza(GPE) . a small number of eligible persons remain and we are working with israeli(NORP) and egyptian(NORP) authorities to support the rest of those who want to leave . ” 

the(ORG) british(ORG) council(ORG) said it was urgently supporting abudagga(PERSON) ’s case .

202403010325.html(CARDINAL) : 

... meets state energy commissioners 

amid widespread rationing and dwindling generation , the minister of power , chief adebayo(PERSON) adelabu(PERSON) has said that the federal government is poised to address challenges facing power supply in the country . 

chief adelabu who stated this during a meeting with state commissioners of energy in abuja(ORG) said irregular power supply in the country would end soon . 

his assurance comes at a time when the country 's power generation is at its lowest level following the decision by gas suppliers to limit supply over(MONEY) $(MONEY) 1.2(MONEY) billion(MONEY) debt . 

a statement by the minister 's special adviser , strategic communications and media relations , mr bolaji(PERSON) tunji(PERSON) said the government would collaborate with state governments to improve supply . 

addressing the forum which had 23(CARDINAL) states in attendance , adelabu(ORG) said with the efforts put in place to address the challenges in the sector , nigerians should be patient as irregular power supply would soon be a thing of the past in the country . 

he said : " we are poised to address the root cause of the electricity challenge . we have done enough diagnostics , we know the cause of the problem , we are now in the implementation stage . we have realised that in the past , temporary solutions were applied to the challenges without dealing with the root cause " . 

the minister who used the opportunity to encourage state governments to take advantage of the new electricity act and get involved , added that the electricity act has brought about unity in diversity . 

he enjoined the federal and state governments to seize the opportunity to work together . 

" you can always call on me to intervene , i will stand by you and i know once the states start to perform and take up further responsibilities , it means i have also performed . 

" when each of the states starts getting involved , there would be healthy rivalry akin to what we used to have in the(DATE) days(DATE) of regional government " . 

adelabu(ORG) drew attention to abia state where geometrics power limited has established a 188(QUANTITY) megawatts(QUANTITY) power generating plant supplying and distributing power to between(CARDINAL) seven(CARDINAL) and(CARDINAL) eight(CARDINAL) local government areas in the state . 

" they enjoy 24(TIME) hours(TIME) power supply , this is what we want states to also adopt . it might look difficult , but with tenacity and if we endure , it is achievable " , he said . 

the minister advised the state government to get involved in distribution networks in their states and also bridging the meter gap . 

" you can then discuss with the discos on how to capitalise your investment . state government can get involved in picking the executive management of the discos . you already have about(PERCENT) 40(PERCENT) percent(PERCENT) of the shares of the discos . you need to discuss with the(ORG) ministry(ORG) of(ORG) finance(ORG) incorporated ( mofi ) on the shares . if a state buys about(CARDINAL) 10(CARDINAL) , 000 meters , all that needs to be done is to agree with the discos on capitalising the investment " . 

earlier , chairman of the forum who is also the commissioner of power and energy , cross river state , prince(PERSON) eka(PERSON) williams(PERSON) re(PERSON) -(PERSON) affirmed unflinching support towards the outstanding visions , ideas and the electricity reforms of the federal government . 

he noted that the electricity act has given the states the responsibility of running the affairs of electricity in the state .

24153206.bristol(CARDINAL) - stabbings - this - cannot - go - on - says - mark - shelford : 

in the(DATE) few(DATE) years(DATE) i have been the police and crime commissioner for avon(PERSON) and somerset(GPE) , i have had the heart - breaking duty of responding to several fatal stabbings . 

it is indeed a heart - breaking duty . the three(CARDINAL) fatal stabbings in bristol(ORG) recently have moved me to speak . 

to think about these children with their whole lives ahead of them , who have had their lives taken , the loss to their families , and also the loss to the families of those who commit these crimes — it makes the heart ache . and things do n’t need to be like this . 

unfortunately , this is not isolated to one(DATE) month(DATE) , one(CARDINAL) area , or one(CARDINAL) gang . 

according to the home office , there were nearly(CARDINAL) 49,000(CARDINAL) crimes in england(GPE) and wales(NORP) involving knives or sharp objects during the(DATE) year(DATE) ending(DATE) september(DATE) 2023(DATE) , and data from nhs digital shows there were 3,775(CARDINAL) “ hospital episodes ” recorded in english(NORP) hospitals in 2022/23(CARDINAL) that were due to assault by sharp objects . 

this can not go on . 

i want us to think about how we , collectively , can stop it . how do we reach out early enough to the young people who end up involved in knife crime ? how can we alter the course of their lives ? 

the home office , councils , and charities are trying hard to fix the problem . i know from working with these caring people that their shoulder is to the wheel . time and money invested in creating opportunities provided by dedicated professionals . but it is not enough . we need answers as to why these interventions are n’t reaching those who need them most . 

i believe as a society , we need to make our young more resilient and resistant to gang culture that leads to crime and violence . 

we need to give them tools and education to resist gang involvement . many say this can not be achieved , but i fervently disagree ; it can if we set our minds to the problem , which we must , we can solve it . there is both a moral and a financial imperative to do so . 

a(DATE) few(DATE) years(DATE) ago(DATE) , i worked for an american(NORP) nato commander who had a saying : “ you ca n’t wring your hands and roll up your sleeves at the same time ; you have to choose one(CARDINAL) or the other . ” 

well , i choose to roll up my sleeves , to try , and if we are to succeed , i need your support . 

there are mechanisms in place to help the young , but they all kick in once they have fallen out of full - time education . 

not only are the costs considerable , but for some , i worry it may be too little too late . the young person is left trying to negotiate life with few or no qualifications . 

how easy will it be for them to find apprentices , to find work , to resist the seemingly easy wins they may be offered by criminal activity ? 

there is a massive emotional and psychological cost of criminalization , to the young people themselves and to their communities . but there is also a very real financial cost . the youth violence commission final report in july(DATE) 2020(DATE) stated : “ the costs associated with serious violence between young people are of an entirely different magnitude : £(MONEY) 10(MONEY) billion(MONEY) over the(DATE) coming(DATE) 10(DATE) years(DATE) assuming rates of violence continue at their current levels . ” 

£(MONEY) 10(MONEY) billion(MONEY) pounds(MONEY) in 10(DATE) years(DATE) ! 

what we are currently doing is not working . “ the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results . ” 

i propose that we must be both brave and bold to make the change we and our young people need . we need to help these young people , and we need to help them now . 

we have the tools , the know - how , the capability , and the money ; what we need is to collectively demonstrate that we also have the gumption — that magic fusion of competence , confidence , resilience , and enthusiasm . the money really is already there ; we simply need to reapportion it . 

what am i talking about ? i am talking about making youth service a compulsory part of the curriculum . i do n’t mean the reintroduction of national service , but i am talking about the duke of edinburgh(PERSON) award scheme , the cadets , and the scouting and guiding movement . 

all of these organisations lead to positive outcomes for our young people through their focus on physical activity , skill acquisition , and community service . these elements generate a sense of accomplishment and self - worth which in turn contribute to improved physical and emotional well - being , resilience , and a sense of belonging within society . 

personally , i joined the scouts followed by the cadets , and i loved my time in both , but do n’t take my word for it . recently , the northampton(ORG) cadets commissioned a study on the benefits of joining a cadet force entitled “ what is the social impact and return on investment resulting from expenditure in cadet forces in the uk(GPE) ? ” . 

it provides compelling evidence : “ the implications of this finding are important for policymakers . given that higher levels of self - efficacy are correlated with being more resilient , doing better at school , and getting a job , it is very possible that being a cadet is , for a young person from an economically disadvantaged background , a key factor that enables them to achieve positive life outcomes . ” 

this is excellent stuff , and it needs to be scaled up . it can be ! 

i am proposing and committed to supporting initiatives to expand the strategic direction of these existing organisations — such as the duke of edinburgh(PERSON) ’s award scheme — with the aim of reaching one(CARDINAL) million(CARDINAL) young people every year over the(DATE) next(DATE) five(DATE) years(DATE) . ideally , i would like even further roll - out of the program to embed the scheme within educational institutions and form part of the national curriculum . 

today(DATE) , i ’m starting a conversation ! 

how do we collaborate with and contribute to raising awareness of , and the broader roll - out of these impactful programs ? is the fact of them being voluntary to join actually a barrier to those who need it most ? please join the conversation and let me know what you think ! 

do you support youth services being part of the national curriculum ? then i urge you to tell your local police and crime commissioner and your mp ! 

do you support youth services being part of the national curriculum ? then i urge you to tell your local police and crime commissioner and your mp !

the - best - way - to - defend - the - right - to - protest - is - to - use - it : 

rishi(ORG) sunak doubled down on the tory crackdown against muslims(NORP) and the right to protest on friday(DATE) night(TIME) . the hastily - organised speech outside downing street is a sign of the panic ripping through the british(NORP) establishment over the(ORG) palestine(ORG) solidarity(ORG) movement(ORG) . 

it came on the(TIME) night(TIME) that george(PERSON) galloway(PERSON) won in the rochdale by - election , where voters punished sunak and keir(PERSON) starmer(PERSON) for supporting israel(GPE) ’s genocide . 

sunak took aim at the(FAC) palestine(FAC) movement(FAC) , claiming , “ in recent(DATE) weeks(DATE) and months(DATE) we have seen a shocking increase in extremist disruption and criminality . what started as protests on our streets have descended into intimidation , threats and planned acts of violence . 

“ now , our democracy itself is a target . council meetings and local events have been stormed . mps(PERSON) do not feel safe in their homes . longstanding parliamentary conventions have been upended because of safety concerns . ” he said the rochdale by - election result was “ beyond alarming ” . 

sunak said the tories would “ redouble our support for the prevent programme ” and “ demand universities stop extremist activity ” . he said it was “ unacceptable to beam antisemitic slogans ” onto parliament — a slur on the slogan , “ from the river to the sea , palestine(GPE) will be free . ” 

it ’s not so much what sunak said that ’s significant , but the fact that he said it at an unplanned broadcast . 

the(ORG) palestine(ORG) movement(ORG) has shaken up british(NORP) politics . it forced out a deeply reactionary home secretary and caused a huge crisis for keir(PERSON) starmer(PERSON) ’s(PERSON) leadership . now , sunak is desperate to repress it — and whip up islamophobia in the hope of shoring up right wing votes in the coming general election . 

the best response is to keep mobilising for palestine(GPE) and not let the state censor our legitimate slogans . and we have to fight back against islamophobia and the tories . 

sunak(PERSON) ’s speech comes after he and other tories had promised more repressive measures . home secretary james(PERSON) cleverly(PERSON) wants to increase the notice period protest organisers have to give police before large demonstrations . he wants to extend it from six(DATE) days(DATE) to a(DATE) couple(DATE) of(DATE) weeks(DATE) . 

the tories want the police to crack down on the protests , with sunak calling on police chiefs to use the powers they have to “ do whatever it takes ” . he said protests outside of mps(PERSON) ’ homes are intimidation and require an “ immediate response ” from police 

these calls for police repression are linked to the tories ramping up islamophobia to undermine the(ORG) palestine(ORG) movement(ORG) . sunak absurdly labelled the movement as “ simply undemocratic ” and claimed , “ there is a growing consensus that mob rule is replacing democratic rule . ” 

sunak gave a lengthy speech on wednesday(TIME) night(TIME) where he sought to demonise palestine(GPE) protesters and paint muslims(NORP) as an enemy within . “ we must also be far bolder and more assertive in defending our british(NORP) values , ” he said . 

“ we ’ve got to end this passive tolerance of words and actions that go against what we stand for . it is as un(NORP) -(NORP) british(NORP) as it is undemocratic . ” 

sunak is wheeling out the islamophobic trope that the protests — which have brought together the left and large numbers of muslims(NORP) — are “ un(NORP) -(NORP) british(NORP) ” . 

tom(PERSON) southerden(PERSON) , amnesty international british(NORP) law and human rights director , said , “ talk of ‘ mob rule ’ wildly exaggerates the issue and risks delegitimising the rights of peaceful protest . ” britain(GPE) “ has undergone a major crackdown on protests in recent(DATE) years(DATE) ” as protests are “ criminalised ” and “ the police being given sweeping powers to prevent protests taking place ” . 

but labour leader keir(PERSON) starmer(PERSON) disgracefully backed sunak . “ the prime minister is right to advocate unity and to condemn the unacceptable and intimidatory behaviour that we have seen recently . it is an important task of leadership to defend our values and the common bonds that hold us together . ” 

he is defending the values of state repression and imperialism . 

the home office announced a policy paper on wednesday(DATE) sinisterly called , “ defending democracy policing protocol ” . the paper says that police should “ direct protesters away ” from mps(PERSON) ’ homes . 

it also says that protesters outside of parliament , town halls , party offices or fundraisers are n’t allowed to prevent use or access to the venue or cause distress to those in the venue . a number of tory mps want to escalate this further , demanding protests outside of parliament or council chambers be completely banned . 

the(ORG) labour(ORG) party(ORG) believes that the home office ’s proposals are sensible , only disagreeing with the language . 

the stop the war coalition , of the organisers of the(ORG) palestine(ORG) demonstrations(ORG) , slammed the move . it committed to “ campaigning energetically ” against any attempts to ban protests outside parliament , council buildings or mps(PERSON) ’ offices . 

the coalition said the freedom of protest “ is needed more than ever ” . “ our politicians are refusing to reflect the demand of the overwhelming majority of the population for an immediate ceasefire in gaza(GPE) , ” it said . “ equating the right to protest with intimidation is completely spurious . ” 

the organisers of the palestine(NORP) marches have put together a dossier of the examples of restrictive and violent policing . 

this includes the attempt to ban the 11(CARDINAL) november demonstration , the constant imposing of restriction orders on the marches and the metropolitan police ’s violent arrests of protesters . 

on top of this , cleverly told palestinian(NORP) protesters to stop their regular protests because they have “ made their point ” . he told the times newspaper that protesters should recognise “ they ’ve made their point loudly and they ’re not adding to it by repeating themselves ” . 

but the march organisers said they will continue to mobilise in support of a free palestine . as long as israel(GPE) ’s genocide in gaza(GPE) continues — backed by the british(NORP) state — ordinary people will take to the streets in rage . 

we must n’t let politicians ’ attempts to demonise muslims(NORP) and the(ORG) palestine(ORG) solidarity(ORG) movement(ORG) and attack the right to protest succeed . the best way to defend protest rights is to use them — against the tory mob in downing street .

prof - takyiwaa - manuh - denies - allegations - of - being - paid - to - oppose - anti - gay - bill : 

a heated exchange has erupted between notable figures regarding the motivations behind opposition to the controversial legislation following the passage of ghana(GPE) ’s anti - lgbtq+ bill . 

a former director of the(ORG) institute(ORG) of(ORG) african(ORG) studies at the(ORG) university(ORG) of(ORG) ghana(ORG) , legon(GPE) , emerita professor takyiwaa manuh , has found herself at the center of this discourse following allegations made by member of parliament for ningo - prampram , samuel(PERSON) nartey(PERSON) george(PERSON) .(PERSON) 

sam(PERSON) george(PERSON) claimed that prof manuh , along with other prominent individuals , has been financially compensated by lgbtq+ groups to advocate against the anti - gay bill . 

in response to these accusations , prof manuh firmly denied the allegations and accused the mp of resorting to insults due to the perceived inadequacy of the bill . she argued that the legislation is redundant given existing laws prohibiting “ unnatural canal activities ” and the abuse of children . moreover , she expressed concerns that the bill could perpetuate discrimination and unwarranted attacks against the lgbt+ community . 

quoting the philosopher socrates , manuh(PERSON) asserted , “ when the debate is lost , insult becomes the loser ’s tool , ” suggesting that george(PERSON) ’s resort to personal attacks indicates a lack of substantive argument in favor of the bill . 

challenging george(PERSON) to provide evidence for his claims , manuh(PERSON) emphasized her intention to uphold her reputation through legal recourse if necessary . she asserted her belief in the protection of the law , stating that the burden of proof lies with those making the allegations . 

meanwhile , in his interview on adom(ORG) fm(ORG) , mp(PERSON) samuel(PERSON) nartey(PERSON) george(PERSON) reiterated his allegations against manuh and other individuals , accusing them of being funded by pro - lgbtq+ groups . he questioned the inconsistency in their opposition to the bill despite the existence of similar provisions in current laws . 

the promotion of human sexual rights and family values bill , now awaiting presidential assent , seeks to criminalize and penalize lgbt(ORG) activities(ORG) and their advocacy in ghana(GPE) . if signed into law , individuals engaging in such activities could face jail terms , while promoters and sponsors could also be subject to legal consequences . 

as the bill awaits presidential action , the nation remains divided , with proponents citing the preservation of traditional family values , while opponents raise concerns about human rights and the potential for discrimination . 

the outcome of this contentious legislative debate now hinges on the decision of president nana(PERSON) addo(PERSON) dankwa(PERSON) akufo(PERSON) -(PERSON) addo(PERSON) , whose approval or rejection of the bill will determine its fate .

contrary to a recent story from high times , new(GPE) mexico(GPE) gov . michelle(PERSON) lujan(PERSON) grisham(PERSON) did not recently sign “ psilocybin memorial legislation . ” we double - checked with her office — memorials of this sort do n’t require the governor ’s signature , but this particular non - binding bill did pass and requests the(ORG) state(ORG) health(ORG) department(ORG) collaborate with the(ORG) university(ORG) of(ORG) new(ORG) mexico(ORG) on a study to “ evaluate the efficacy of psilocybin - based therapeutic treatments and the establishment of a program allowing the use of psilocybin mushrooms for therapeutic medical treatments . ” the governor does support the memorial “ in concept , ” communications director michael(PERSON) coleman(PERSON) writes to sfr(ORG) . “ she generally supports innovative and responsible research and treatment to address depression , addiction , post - traumatic stress disorder and other mental health challenges . ” intrigued by the concept ? power of the black dollar : funding entrepreneurs in tech 

black entrepreneurs in sectors like tech have historically faced disproportionate funding challenges that further stifle innovation for everyone.learn more 

the vice president said minority - owned businesses have " received a fraction of federal contracts , often because the relationships are not there . " 

vice president kamala(PERSON) harris(PERSON) , during remarks on a trip to north(GPE) carolina(GPE) , said the biden administration is on track to meet its goal of increasing federal contracts for minority - owned businesses by 50(PERCENT) %(PERCENT) .

vice president harris(PERSON) was there to announce that the biden administration would be injecting a new $(MONEY) 92(MONEY) million(MONEY) to be used mainly for early - stage startups in north(GPE) carolina(GPE) . nc(GPE) invest focuses on growing small businesses .

black entrepreneurs in sectors like tech have historically faced disproportionate funding challenges that further stifle innovation for everyone.learn more

two(CARDINAL) other states were also holding republican(NORP) elections saturday(DATE) : idaho(GPE) and michigan(GPE) . but none of them were primaries . all were caucuses , which limit turnout by requiring participants to arrive at a specific time and usually to stay for a certain period to participate in a more formal process . 

caucus specifics vary from state to state , but they usually involve hearing speeches and then casting a vote . 

the(ORG) associated(ORG) press(ORG) called missouri(GPE) for trump at 12:40(TIME) p.m.(TIME) et . 

trump(PERSON) has won every single republican(NORP) nominating contest since the(DATE) year(DATE) began . he will face his only serious remaining challenger , former south(GPE) carolina(GPE) gov . nikki(PERSON) haley(PERSON) , in the numerous elections being held march(DATE) 5(DATE) , which is known as super tuesday(DATE) .

caucuses limited participation 

in both idaho(GPE) and missouri(GPE) , state lawmakers canceled the republican(NORP) primary and replaced it with caucuses . 

this gave a small percentage of republicans(NORP) in the state control over who the party nominates . 

the last time idaho(GPE) held caucuses instead of a primary , in 2012(DATE) , only(CARDINAL) about(CARDINAL) 45,000(CARDINAL) people took part . that was about(CARDINAL) a(CARDINAL) fifth(CARDINAL) of all registered republicans(NORP) in the state . 

the timing of the caucuses was also an obstacle for many . idaho(GPE) , which is split between the mountain and pacific time zones , held its caucuses at 12:30(TIME) or(TIME) 1:30(TIME) in(TIME) the(TIME) afternoon(TIME) . missouri(GPE) held its caucuses at 10(TIME) a.m.(TIME) ct . 

michigan(GPE) ’s caucus convention was even more restricted 

in michigan(GPE) , which held its caucuses at 10(TIME) a.m.(TIME) et , the average voter could n’t even take part .

but there was a scheduling conflict between the date set by michigan(GPE) ’s legislature , which is controlled by democrats(NORP) , and rules for the republican(NORP) nominating calendar set by the(ORG) republican(ORG) national(ORG) committee(ORG) . 

so the(ORG) michigan(ORG) gop(ORG) created a hybrid system in which a majority of the state ’s 55(CARDINAL) delegates are allocated based on a caucus convention . 

the caucus convention , being held saturday(DATE) , brought together around 2,000(CARDINAL) party activists from around the state who were selected at the county level .
